ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 1221
AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR
THE CITY OF FULTON, WHITESIDE COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY.
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, has
completed the 2003 S-1 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Fulton, which supplement contains all ordinances of a general and permanent
nature enacted since the prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City
of Fulton; and
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision or
addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections of the Illinois Code; and
WHEREAS, it is the intent of the City Council of the City of Fulton to accept
these updated sections in accordance with the changes of the law of the State
of Illinois; and
WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the
municipality and for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health,
safety and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance take effect
at an early date;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF FULTON,
WHITESIDE COUNTY, ILLINOIS:
Section 1.   That the 2003 S-1 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City
of Fulton as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati,
Ohio, and as attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by reference as
if set out in its entirety.
Section 2.   Such supplement shall be deemed published as the day of its
adoption and approval by the City Council and the Clerk of the City of Fulton
is hereby authorized and ordered to insert such supplement into the copy of the
Code of Ordinances kept on file in the Office of the Clerk.
Section 3.   This ordinance is declared to be an emergency measure necessary
for the immediate preservation of the peace, health, safety and general welfare
of the people of this municipality, and shall take effect at the earliest date
provided by law.
PASSED AND ADOPTED by the Mayor and City Council of the City of Fulton,
Whiteside County, Illinois on this 19th day of August, 2003, and deposited and
filed in the office of the City Clerk in said City on that date pursuant to
roll call vote as follows:
AYES:      5
NAYS:   0
ABSENT:   2
                Jeanne M. Kettler /s/
               City Clerk of the City of Fulton, Illinois
APPROVED by the Mayor of the City of Fulton, Illinois, this 19th day of August,
2003.
                Howard Van Zuiden /s/
               Mayor of the City of Fulton, Illinois
ATTEST:
Jeanne M. Kettler /s/
Clerk of the City of Fulton, Illinois
   Published in pamphlet form this 19th day of August, 2003.
ORDINANCE NO. 1254
AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR
THE CITY OF FULTON, WHITESIDE COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY.
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, has
completed the 2004 S-2 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Fulton, which supplement contains all ordinances of a general and permanent
nature enacted since the prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City
of Fulton; and

addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections of the Illinois Code; and
WHEREAS, it is the intent of the City Council of the City of Fulton to accept
these updated sections in accordance with the changes of the law of the State
of Illinois; and
WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the
municipality and for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health,
safety and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance take effect
at an early date;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF FULTON,
WHITESIDE COUNTY, ILLINOIS:
Section 1.   That the 2004 S-2 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City
of Fulton as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati,
Ohio, and as attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by reference as
if set out in its entirety.

adoption and approval by the City Council and the Clerk of the City of Fulton

Section 3.   This Ordinance is declared to be an emergency measure necessary
for the immediate preservation of the peace, health, safety and general welfare
of the people of this municipality, and shall take effect at the earliest date
provided by law.

nature enacted since the prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City
of Fulton; and

addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections of the Illinois Code; and
WHEREAS, it is the intent of the City Council of the City of Fulton to accept
these updated sections in accordance with the changes of the law of the State
of Illinois; and
WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the
municipality and for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health,
safety and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance take effect
at an early date;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF FULTON,
WHITESIDE COUNTY, ILLINOIS:

provided by law.

ORDINANCE NO. 1390
AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR
THE CITY OF FULTON, WHITESIDE COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY.
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, has
completed the 2009 S-4 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Fulton, which supplement contains all ordinances of a general and permanent
nature enacted since the prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City
of Fulton; and
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision or
addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections of the Illinois Code; and
WHEREAS, it is the intent of the City Council of the City of Fulton to accept
these updated sections in accordance with the changes of the law of the State
of Illinois; and
WHEREAS, it is necessary to provide for the usual daily operation of the
municipality and for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health,
safety and general welfare of the municipality that this ordinance take effect
at an early date;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF FULTON,
WHITESIDE COUNTY, ILLINOIS:
Section 1.   That the 2009 S-4 supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City
of Fulton as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati,
Ohio and as attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by reference as
if set out in its entirety.
Section 2.   Such supplement shall be deemed published as of the day of its
adoption and approval by the City Council and the Clerk of the City of Fulton
is hereby authorized and ordered to insert such supplement into the copy of the
Code of Ordinances kept on file in the Office of the Clerk.
Section 3.   This Ordinance is declared to be an emergency measure necessary
for the immediate preservation of the peace, health, safety and general welfare
of the people of this municipality, and shall take effect at the earliest date
provided by law.
PASSED AND ADOPTED by the Mayor and City Council of the City of Fulton,
Whiteside County, Illinois on this 1st day of June, 2009, and deposited and
filed in the office of the City Clerk in said City on that date pursuant to

§ 10.01 TITLE OF CODE.
   This codification of ordinances by and for the city of Fulton, Illinois,
shall be designated as the Code of Fulton, and may be so cited.
§ 10.02 INTERPRETATION.
   Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law or implication required, the
same rules of construction, definition, and application shall govern the
interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation of state law.
§ 10.03 APPLICATION TO FUTURE ORDINANCES.
   All provisions of Title I compatible with future legislation shall apply to
ordinances hereafter adopted, amending or supplementing this code unless
otherwise specifically provided.
§ 10.04 CAPTIONS.
   Headings and captions used in this code other than the title, chapter, and
section numbers are employed for reference purposes only and shall not be
deemed a part of the text of any section.
§ 10.05 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   General rule. Words and phrases shall be taken in their plain, or
ordinary and usual sense. However, technical words and phrases having a
peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be understood according to their
technical import.
   (B)   For the purpose of this code, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY or MUNICIPALITY. The City of Fulton, Illinois.
   CITY COUNCIL or COUNCIL. The legislative body of the city.
   CODE, THIS CODE or THIS CODE OF ORDINANCES. This municipal code as modified
by amendment, revision, and adoption of new titles, chapters, or sections.
   COUNTY. Whiteside County, Illinois.
   MAY. The act referred to is permissive.
   MONTH. A calendar month.
   OATH. An affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be
substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words SWEAR and SWORN shall be
equivalent to the words AFFIRM and AFFIRMED.
   OFFICER, OFFICE, EMPLOYEE, COMMISSION, or DEPARTMENT. An officer, office,
employee, commission, or department of this city unless the context clearly
requires otherwise.
   PERSON. Extends to and includes person, persons, firm, corporation,
copartnership, trustee, lessee, or receiver. Whenever used in any clause
prescribing and imposing a penalty, the terms PERSON or WHOEVER as applied to
any unincorporated entity shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as
applied to corporations, the officers or agents thereof.
   PRECEDING or FOLLOWING. Next before or next after, respectively.
   SHALL. The act referred to is mandatory.
   SIGNATURE or SUBSCRIPTION. Includes a mark when the person cannot write.
   STATE. The State of Illinois.
   SUBCHAPTER. A division of a chapter, designated in this code by a heading in
the chapter analysis and a capitalized heading in the body of the chapter,
setting apart a group of sections related by the subject matter of the heading.
Not all chapters have subchapters.
   WRITTEN. Any representation of words, letters, or figures, whether by
printing or otherwise.
   YEAR. A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed; equivalent to the words
YEAR OF OUR LORD.
§ 10.06 RULES OF INTERPRETATION.
   The construction of all ordinances of this city shall be by the following
rules, unless such construction is plainly repugnant to the intent of the City
Council or of the context of the same ordinance:
   (A)    AND or OR. Either conjunction shall include the other as if written
“and/or,” if the sense requires it.
   (B)   Acts by assistants. When a statute or ordinance requires an act to be
done which, by law, an agent or deputy as well may do as the principal, such
requisition shall be satisfied by the performance of such act by an authorized
agent or deputy.
   (C)   Gender; singular and plural; tenses. Words denoting the masculine
gender shall be deemed to include the feminine and neuter genders; words in the
singular shall include the plural, and words in the plural shall include the
singular; the use of a verb in the present tense shall include the future, if
applicable.
   (D)   General term. A general term following specific enumeration of terms
is not to be limited to the class enumerated unless expressly so limited.
§ 10.07 SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of this code as now or later amended or its application to
any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect
other provisions that can be given effect without the invalid provision or
application.
§ 10.08 REFERENCE TO OTHER SECTIONS.
   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof, such
reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered unless the subject matter is
changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
§ 10.09 REFERENCE TO OFFICES.
   Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any
office, officer, or employee of this city exercising the powers, duties, or
functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any transfer of
functions or change in the official title of the functionary.
§ 10.10 ERRORS AND OMISSIONS.
   If a manifest error is discovered, consisting of the misspelling of any
words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention of
the provisions affected; the use of a word or words to which no meaning can be
attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was clearly
intended to express such intent, such spelling shall be corrected and such word
or words supplied, omitted, or substituted as will conform with the manifest
intention, and the provisions shall have the same effect as though the correct
words were contained in the text as originally published. No alteration shall
be made or permitted if any question exists regarding the nature or extent of
such error.
§ 10.11 OFFICIAL TIME.
   The official time, as established by applicable state/federal laws, shall be
the official time within this city for the transaction of all city business.
§ 10.12 COMPUTATION OF TIME.
   Except when otherwise provided, the time within which an act is required to
be done or a payment under this code is to be made shall be computed by
excluding the first day and including the last day. When the last day is a
Saturday, Sunday or a city holiday, it shall also be excluded. City holidays
shall be defined as the days other than a Saturday or Sunday when the city
offices are officially closed for business.
(Ord. 1161, passed 6-19-01)
§ 10.13 ORDINANCES REPEALED.
   This code, from and after its effective date, shall contain all of the
provisions of a general nature pertaining to the subjects herein enumerated and
embraced. All prior ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated by this code
shall be deemed repealed from and after the effective date of this code.
§ 10.14 ORDINANCES UNAFFECTED.
   All ordinances of a temporary or special nature and all other ordinances
pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall remain in full force and
effect unless herein repealed expressly or by necessary implication.
§ 10.15 EFFECTIVE DATE OF ORDINANCES.
   All ordinances passed by the City Council requiring publication shall take
effect from and after the due publication thereof, unless otherwise expressly
provided. Ordinances not requiring publication shall take effect from their
passage, unless otherwise expressly provided.
§ 10.16 REPEAL OR MODIFICATION OF ORDINANCE.
   (A)   Whenever any ordinance or part of an ordinance shall be repealed or
modified by a subsequent ordinance, the ordinance or part of an ordinance thus
repealed or modified shall continue in force until the due publication of the
ordinance repealing or modifying it when publication is required to give effect
thereto, unless otherwise expressly provided.
   (B)   No suit, proceedings, right, fine, forfeiture, or penalty instituted,
created, given, secured, or accrued under any ordinance previous to its repeal
shall in any way be affected, released, or discharged, but may be prosecuted,
enjoyed, and recovered as fully as if the ordinance had continued in force
unless it is otherwise expressly provided.
   (C)   When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause, or provision
shall by itself repealed, the repeal shall not be construed to revive the
former ordinance, clause, or provision, unless it is expressly provided.
§ 10.17 ORDINANCES WHICH AMEND OR SUPPLEMENT CODE.
   (A)   If the City Council shall desire to amend any existing chapter or
section of this code, the chapter or section shall be specifically repealed and
a new chapter or section, containing the desired amendment, substituted in its
place.
   (B)   Any ordinance which is proposed to add to the existing code a new
chapter or section shall indicate, with reference to the arrangement of this
code, the proper number of such chapter or section. In addition to such
indication thereof as may appear in the text of the proposed ordinance, a
caption or title shall be shown in concise form above the ordinance.
§ 10.18 SECTION HISTORIES; STATUTORY REFERENCES.
   (A)   As histories for the code sections, the specific number and passage
date of the original ordinance, and the most recent three amending ordinances,
if any, are listed following the text of the code section. Example: (Ord. 10,
passed 5-13-60; Am. Ord. 15, passed 1-1-70; Am. Ord. 20, passed
1-1-80; Am. Ord. 25, passed 1-1-85)
   (B)   (1)   If a statutory cite is included in the history, this indicates
that the text of the section reads substantially the same as the statute.
Example: ILCS Ch. 24, § 3-4-2.
(Ord. 10, passed 1-17-80; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-1-85).
      (2)   If a statutory cite is set forth as a “statutory reference”
following the text of the section, this indicates that the reader should refer
to that statute for further information.
Example:
   § 31.10 MAYOR.
      The Mayor shall preside at all meetings of the City Council.
   (Ord. 10, passed 1-1-80)
   Statutory reference:
      For the powers and duties of the Mayor, see ILCS Ch. 24, § 3-11-6
§ 10.19 WAIVER OF FEES.
   The City Council shall have the discretion to waive any fee required by a
city ordinance, or any provision of the city code, as provided herein, except
when the ordinance or provision of the city code specifically states that the
fee cannot be waived at the discretion of the City Council. Such fee may only
be waived if a motion is duly passed by an affirmative vote of not less than
three-fourths of the City Council. Such motion shall also provide the specific
reasons why the City Council is voting to waive the fee in each particular
situation and why such waiver of fee will be in the best interests of the city.
(Ord. 933, passed 5-7-91)
§ 10.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this code for
which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon conviction, be
subject to a fine not less than $100, and not more than $750. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during which a violation occurs
or continues.
(Am. Ord. 1713, passed - -)
CHAPTER 11: CITY STANDARDS
Section
   
11.01   Corporate seal
   
11.02   City boundaries
   
11.03   Wards
   
11.04   Daylight savings time adopted; compliance required
§ 11.01 CORPORATE SEAL.
   The corporate seal of the city shall be a circular disc, with the words "The
Corporate Seal of the City of Fulton" on the periphery thereof, and the words
"Whiteside County, Illinois" enclosed therein.
(‘82 Code, § 1.08.010)
§ 11.02 CITY BOUNDARIES.
   The city of Fulton shall embrace all of the territory within the following
described limits, all located in the county of Whiteside and state of Illinois:
beginning at a point on the north line of Section Thirty Three, Township Twenty
Two North, Range 3 East of the Fourth Principal Meridian, in Whiteside County,
Illinois where the north line of the section is intersected by the east line of
the right-of-way of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company;
running thence west along and upon said north line of said Section to the
Mississippi River; running thence west on the north line of said Section
extended to the center of the channel of the Mississippi River; running thence
northerly up the center of the channel of the Mississippi River to a point due
west of the center of the mouth of the Cattail Slough, so called; running
thence due east to the center of the mouth of the Cattail Slough, so called;
running thence easterly and southerly along the center of the Cattail Slough,
so called, to the point where the center of the Cattail Slough, so called,
intersects the east line of Section Twenty-One Township and Range aforesaid;
running thence due east to the west line of the Public Highway running
southerly through the northeast quarter of the Southwest Quarter of Section
Twenty-One; running thence southerly and westerly along and upon the westerly
and northerly line of the Highway to a point twelve rods west of the center
line of the Cattail Slough, so called, and twelve rods west of the center of
the culvert now across the Highway; running thence due south across the Highway
to the south line of the Highway; running thence due east to the east line of
the right-of-way of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company;
running thence southerly and westerly along and upon the said east line of the
said right-of-way of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company to the
point where the east line of the right-of-way intersects the east line of
Section Twenty Eight, in the Township and Range aforesaid; running thence south
along and upon said east line of Section Twenty-Eight to the point where said
east line of Section Twenty-Eight intersects the south line of the abandoned
right-of-way of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company, located in the
west one half of the southwest quarter of Section Twenty-Seven, in the Township
and Range aforesaid; running thence west along and upon the south line of the
abandoned right-of-way of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company to the
east line of the right-of-way of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway
Company; running thence southerly and westerly along and upon the right-of-way
of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company to the point of
beginning; and, also, all that part of the Southwest quarter of Section Twenty-
Seven in the Township and Range aforesaid lying south of the abandoned right-
of-way of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company and north of the center
line of the Public Highway running from the city of Fulton to the city of
Morrison, in Whiteside County, Illinois, and known as Illinois State Bond Issue
Route No. 6, and U. S. Route No. 30, and north of the center line of the cement
highway running easterly from the east line of the Southeast quarter of Section
Twenty-Eight in the Township and Range aforesaid to said U. S. Route No. 30;
and excepting and excluding a tract of land one hundred feet in width, the
center line of which is as follows; commencing on the east line of 14th Street
in the city of Fulton, in the county and state aforesaid, and on the center
line of 10th Avenue in the city, and running thence east on the center line of
10th Avenue, extended, to the easterly corporation limit of the city.
(‘82 Code, § 1.12.010)
§ 11.03 WARDS.
   The territory embraced within the corporate limits of the city is divided
into four wards, as follows:
   (A)   Fourth ward is all that portion of the territory embraced within the
corporate limits which lies north of the line drawn as follows: beginning at
the eastern boundary of the city at a point due east of the center line of 4th
Avenue, in the city and running thence west with the center line of the avenue
to the western boundary of the city.
   (B)   First ward is all that portion of the territory embraced within the
corporate limits which lies south of the last above-described line and north of
a line drawn as follows: beginning at the eastern boundary of the city at a
point due east of the center line of 10th Avenue, in the city and running
thence west with the center line of the avenue to the western boundary of the
city.
   (C)   Second ward is all that portion of the territory embraced within the
corporate limits of the city which lies south of the last above-described line
and north of a line drawn as follows: beginning at the eastern boundary of the
city at a point due east of the centerline of 14th Avenue in the city and
running thence west with the centerline of 14th Avenue to the western boundary
of the city.
   (D)   Third ward is all that portion of the territory embraced within the
corporate limits which lies south of the line last above described.
(‘82 Code, § 1.16.010) (Ord. 1146, passed 11-7-00)
§ 11.04 DAYLIGHT SAVINGS TIME ADOPTED; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   (A)   Central Standard Time from and after the passage of the ordinance
codified in this chapter shall be the official time within the city for the
transaction of all city business except that from 2:00 a.m., on Sunday, on the
last Saturday in April, continuously to 2:00 a.m., on Sunday, on the last
Saturday in October, the official time of the city shall be advanced one hour
and all legal and official proceedings of the city shall be regulated thereby
in accordance with the advanced time.
(‘82 Code, § 1.20.010)
   (B)   All clocks and time pieces on city premises shall be set and run
according to the official time as provided in division (A) of this section. All
persons residing within the city are requested to set any and all clocks or
other time pieces under their control within the city in accordance with the
official time as provided in this chapter.
(‘82 Code, § 1.20.020)
(Ord. 510, passed - -59).
CHAPTER 12: STATE OF EMERGENCY
Section
   
12.01   Definitions
   
12.02   Declaration
   
12.03   Curfew authorized
   
12.04   Orders authorized
   
12.05   Duration
   
12.06   Notice
   
12.07   Effect on other ordinances
 
   
12.99   Penalty
§ 12.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CURFEW. A prohibition against any person walking, running, loitering,
standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant
premises within the corporate limits of the city except officials of any
governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty with reference to
said civil emergency and essential persons identified in the order establishing
the curfew.
   EMERGENCY. A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual
force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power
to execute by three or more persons acting together without authority of law;
or any natural disaster, epidemic, or manmade calamity, including outbreak of
disease, flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion, or
eminent threat of any of those events within the corporate limits of the city,
resulting in or threatening the death or injury of persons or the destruction
of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to
protect the public health, safety and welfare.
(Ord. 1654, passed 6-22-20)
§ 12.02 DECLARATION.
   Whenever an emergency, as defined in §
12.01 exists, the Mayor is authorized to declare the existence of a local state
of emergency by means of a written declaration of the Mayor, under oath,
setting forth the facts which constitute the emergency, describing the nature
of the emergency and declaring that a local state of emergency exists in
accordance with the definitions set forth in this section. This declaration
must be filed with the municipal clerk as soon as practicable after issuance.
(Ord. 1654, passed 6-22-20)
§ 12.03 CURFEW AUTHORIZED.
   After proclamation of a local state of emergency by the Mayor, he or she may
order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the city or to
the city as a whole, as he or she deems reasonable and advisable, and
applicable during such hours of the day or night as he or she deems necessary
in the interest of the public safety and welfare.
(Ord. 1654, passed 6-22-20)
§ 12.04 ORDERS AUTHORIZED.
   After the proclamation of a local state of emergency, the Mayor may also, in
the interest of public safety and welfare, and to address this issue caused
threatened by the emergency, make take any or all of the following actions by
executive order during the state of emergency:
   (A)   All actions reasonably necessary to respond to the emergency;
   (B)   Approve previously appropriated expenditures of the city for the
purpose of continuing the operations of the municipality;
   (C)   In the event the local state of emergency extends beyond the current
fiscal year and a new budget has not been approved, the Mayor shall be
authorized to approve new spending by the city during the existence of the
local state of emergency;
   (D)   Order the closing of all retail liquor stores, including taverns and
private clubs or portions thereof wherein the consumption of intoxicating
liquor and beer is permitted;
   (E)   Order the discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic liquor by any
wholesaler or retailer;
   (F)   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away
gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container
other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle;
   (G)   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or
giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever.
(Ord. 1654, passed 6-22-20)
§ 12.05 DURATION.
   The declaration herein authorized shall be effective for a period of up to
30 days or until the adjournment of the next regular or special meeting of the
City Council, whichever comes first, unless sooner terminated by a proclamation
of the Mayor, or, his or her interim emergency successor, indicating that the
civil emergency no longer exists. The Mayor or his or her interim emergency
successor, shall have the power to re-proclaim the existence of an emergency at
the end of each 30-day period during the time said emergency exists.
(Ord. 1654, passed 6-22-20)
§ 12.06 NOTICE.
   Upon issuing the proclamation herein authorized, the City Clerk shall notify
the news media situated within the city, and shall cause at least four copies
of the proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency and any curfew to
be posted at the following places within the city: the City Hall, the police
station, the post office, and in the area of any curfew.
(Ord. 1654, passed 6-22-20)
§ 12.07 EFFECT ON OTHER ORDINANCES.
   Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to impair the powers
contained in this code, giving powers to the Police and Fire Departments, but
shall be construed together with existing ordinances now in effect for the
safety and welfare of the citizens of the city.
(Ord. 1654, passed 6-22-20)
§ 12.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating the provisions of this section or executive orders
issued pursuant hereto shall be guilty of an offense against the city and shall
be punished as provided by §
10.99.
(Ord. 1654, passed 6-22-20)

MAYOR
§ 30.01 TERM OF OFFICE.
   The Mayor shall be elected for a term of four years and shall serve until
his or her successor is elected and qualified as is provided by statute.
(‘82 Code, § 2.04.010)
§ 30.02 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Mayor shall be chief executive officer of the city and shall perform
such duties as may be required of him or her by statute or ordinance. He or she
shall have supervision over all of the executive officers and employees of the
city and shall have the power and authority to inspect all books and records
pertaining to the city affairs and kept by any officer or employee of the city,
at any reasonable time.
(‘82 Code, § 2.04.020)
§ 30.03 APPOINTIVE POWERS.
   The Mayor shall appoint, by and with the advice and consent of the City
Council, all officers of the city whose election or appointment is not
otherwise provided for. Any vacancies occurring in any appointive office shall
be filled in the same manner.
(‘82 Code, § 2.04.040)
§ 30.04 DELEGATION AND ASSIGNMENT OF POWERS AND DUTIES.
   Whenever there is a dispute as to the respective duties or powers of any
appointed officer of the city, this dispute shall be settled by the Mayor after
consultation with the City Attorney; and the Mayor shall have the power to
delegate to any appointed officer any duty which is to be performed when no
specific officer has been directed to perform that duty.
(‘82 Code, § 2.04.050)
§ 30.05 BOND.
   Before entering upon his or her duties, the Mayor shall give bond in such
amount and with such sureties as may be required by the City Council,
conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of his or her office.
He or she shall take the oath of office as prescribed by statute and shall
receive such compensation as may be set from time to time by the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.04.030)
§ 30.06 MAYOR PRO TEM.
   During a temporary absence or disability of the Mayor, the City Council
shall elect one of its number to act as Mayor Pro Tem, who during the absence
or disability of the Mayor shall possess the powers of Mayor, as is provided by
statute.
(‘82 Code, § 2.04.060)
CITY COUNCIL
§ 30.20 TERM OF OFFICE.
   The members of the City Council shall be elected and serve for a four year
term as is provided by statute. The Council shall be the legislative division
of the city government and shall perform such duties and have such powers as
may be authorized by statute.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.010)
§ 30.21 LOCATION AND SCHEDULE OF MEETINGS.
   The regular meetings of the City Council shall be held on the second Monday
and fourth Monday of each month at the hour of 5:30 p.m. in the Council Room in
the City Hall in Fulton, beginning with the month of June, 2022. The corporate
authorities shall give public notice of the schedule of regular meetings at the
beginning of each calendar or fiscal year and shall state the regular dates,
times and places of such meetings pursuant to ILCS Ch. 5, Act 120, § 2.02.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.020) (Am. Ord. 1076, passed 10-7-97; Am. Ord. 1154, passed 3-
6-01; Am. Ord. 1233, passed 2-18-04; Am. Ord. 1242, passed 7-6-04; Am. Ord.
1570, passed 8-21-17; Am. Ord. 1676, passed 4-26-21; Am. Ord. 1698, passed 4-
11-22)
§ 30.22 SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   Special meetings of the Council may be called by the Mayor or any three
Alder persons; provided, a written notice of such meeting shall be given to
each member of the Council at least 24 hours before the time of such meeting.
Public notice of any special meeting, of any rescheduled regular meeting or of
any recommended meeting shall also be given at least 24 hours before such
meeting, pursuant to ILCS Ch. 5, Act 120, § 2.02. If a special meeting should
be called at a citizen's request, the citizen shall pay $25 for each attending
elected official.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.030)
§ 30.23 QUORUM.
   A majority of the elected members of the Council shall constitute a quorum
thereof, but no ordinance shall be passed except by a favorable vote of a
majority of the elected members as is provided by statute.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.040)
§ 30.24 STANDING COMMITTEES.
   The following shall be the standing committees of the City Council:
   (A)   Budget Committee. Concerns matters of finance.
   (B)   Public Property. Concerns matters relative to city buildings, parks,
streets and alleys.
   (C)   Economic Development. Concerns matters relative to economic
development, tourism, city planning, land use and zoning.
   (D)   Public Safety. Concerns matters of police and law enforcement
generally.
   (E)   Parks and Recreation. Concerns matters on parks and recreational
activities.
   (F)   Marina. Concerns matters relative to the City Marina facilities
   (G)   Personnel. Concerns matters relative to the city employees and
personnel issues.
   (H)   Tourism. Concerns matters related to tourism.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.050) (Am. Ord. 1566, passed 5-15-17; Am. Ord. 1572, passed 7-
17-17; Am. Ord. 1703, passed 6-13-22; Am. Ord. 1721, passed 6-12-23)
§ 30.25 SPECIAL COMMITTEES.
   The Mayor shall appoint such special committees as he or she may deem
necessary or as may be directed by the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.060)
§ 30.26 MEMBERSHIP AND ORGANIZATION OF COMMITTEES.
   The Mayor shall appoint the membership of all standing and special
committees and shall designate the Chairman thereof. Every committee shall
consist of three members including the Chairman, unless the Council shall
provide otherwise.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.070)
§ 30.27 MINUTES AND RECORDS.
   The City Clerk shall keep the minutes and records of the Council
proceedings.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.080)
§ 30.28 RECISSION OF VOTE OR ACTION; NUMBER OF MEMBERS REQUIRED.
   No vote or action of the Council shall be rescinded at any special meeting
unless there shall be present at such special meeting as many members of the
Council as were present at the meeting when such vote or action was taken, as
provided by statute.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.090)
§ 30.29 ADDRESSING MEETINGS; CONSENT OF COUNCIL REQUIRED.
   The city recognizes the Illinois Open Meetings Act provides that any person
shall be permitted an opportunity to address public officials under rules
established by the city. The City Council by majority votes of its members then
holding office shall establish rules for public participation to balance the
rights of individuals to address the Council with the Council's need to
maintain meeting decorum and efficiencies. The rules may be amended from time
to time by majority vote of the members of the City Council then holding
office.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.100) (Ord. 1521, passed 1-19-15)
§ 30.30 GOVERNING RULES.
   Robert's Rules of Order shall govern the deliberations of the City Council
except when in conflict with any of the foregoing rules.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.110)
§ 30.31 DISTURBING MEETINGS.
   It is unlawful to disturb any regular or special meeting of the City Council
or any committee thereof, or to behave in a disorderly manner at any such
meeting.
(‘82 Code, § 2.08.120)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 30.32 CONSENT AGENDA.
   A consent agenda shall be prepared under the direction of the City
Administrator and shall include the approval of minutes of council meetings,
bills to be approved, and such matters the Administrator shall determine are
routine. All items listed on the consent agenda will be enacted by one motion
and one vote, which shall be a roll call vote. The City Clerk shall enter a
single note in the journal under the designation "Consent Agenda". An omnibus
vote shall be with like effect as if the vote of each item was voted upon
separately. Upon the request of the Mayor or an Alderman an item will be
removed from the consent agenda and considered individually after all other
items of business on the consent agenda.
(Ord. 1535, passed 1-18-16)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 31.001 APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall apply alike to all officers or
employees of the city, regardless of the time of creating the office or the
time of the appointment of the officer.
(‘82 Code, § 2.44.010)
§ 31.002 MAYOR; APPOINTIVE POWERS.
   The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Council, shall make all
appointments to fill all appointive offices.
(‘82 Code, § 2.44.020) (Am. Ord. 1574, passed 9-5-17)
§ 31.003 APPOINTIVE OFFICER; TERM, ASSIGNMENT OF ADDITIONAL DUTIES.
   (A)   Term. Every appointive officer of the city shall hold office for a
term of one year or until his or her successor is appointed and qualified
unless it is otherwise provided by ordinance. Employees selected shall serve so
long as their services are desired, provided, however, that in case of a
vacancy in any appointive office, the Mayor shall have power to appoint any
qualified person to serve as such officer until such person or officer may be
approved by the Council, but not to exceed 30 days.
(‘82 Code, § 2.44.030)
   (B)   Assignment of additional duties. The Mayor shall have power to assign
to any appointive officer any duty which is not assigned by ordinance to some
other specific officer and shall determine disputes or questions relating to
the respective powers or duties of officers.
(‘82 Code, § 2.44.040)
§ 31.004 RECORDS OPEN TO INSPECTION.
   All records kept by any officer of the city shall be open to inspection by
the Mayor or any member of the Council, at reasonable times, whether such
records are required to be kept by ordinance or not.
(‘82 Code, § 2.44.050)
§ 31.005 TRANSMITTAL OF MONEYS RECEIVED TO CLERK.
   Every officer shall, within a reasonable time not to exceed 30 days, turn
over all moneys received by him or her in his or her official capacity to the
Clerk with a statement showing the source from which the same was received.
(‘82 Code, § 2.44.060)
§ 31.006 OATH AND BOND.
   Every officer shall, before entering upon his or her duties as such officer,
take the oath prescribed by statute, and shall, if required by the Council,
give bond in such amount as may be determined by the Council and with such
sureties as it may approve, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
duties of his or her office.
(‘82 Code, § 2.44.070)
§ 31.007 COMPENSATION.
Publisher's Note: This Section has been AMENDED by new legislation (Ord. 1765,
adopted 6-23-2025). The text of the amendment will be incorporated below when
the ordinance is codified.
   The following city officers shall be paid compensation as set forth
effective September 26, 2022:
   (A)   City Mayor: $300 per first meeting attended plus $75 per additional
meeting attended.
   (B)   City Alderperson: $75 per meeting attended.
   (C)   City Clerk: $262.50 per meeting attended, $75 per additional meeting
attended, plus up to eight hours per week at $20 per hour.
(Am. Ord. 1708, passed 9-26-22)
§ 31.008 STATE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT.
   (A)   The regulations of ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 5-15 and Article 10, ILCS
Ch. 5, Act 430, §§ 10-10 through 10-40 of the State Officials and Employees
Ethics Act, ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 1-1 et seq., (hereinafter referred to as the
"Act" in this chapter) are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to
the officers and employees of the city to the extent required by ILCS Ch. 5,
Act 430, § 70-5.
   (B)   The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or
accepted under the Act, by any officer or any employee of the city, is hereby
prohibited.
   (C)   The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an
officer or employee of the city under the Act, is hereby prohibited.
   (D)   The participation in political activities prohibited under the Act, by
any officer or employee of the city, is hereby prohibited.
   (E)   For purposes of this chapter, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall
be defined as set forth in ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 70-5(c).
   (F)   The penalties for violations of this chapter shall be the same as
those penalties set forth in ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 50-5 for similar violations
of the Act.
   (G)   This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing
ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of city officers and
employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less
restrictive than this section except as specifically set forth herein, however,
the provisions of this section shall prevail in accordance with the provisions
of ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 70-5(a).
   (H)   Any amendment to the Act that becomes effective after the effective
date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by reference and
shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of
gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes
its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be
incorporated into this section by reference without formal action by the
corporate authorities of the city.
   (I)   If the Illinois Supreme Court declares the Act unconstitutional in its
entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois
Supreme Court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals
or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action by
the corporate authorities of the city if the Act is found unconstitutional by
the Illinois Supreme Court.
   (J)   If the Illinois Supreme Court declares part of the Act
unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the Act,
or does not address the remainder of the Act, then the remainder of the Act as
adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that
part of this section relating to the part of the Act found unconstitutional
shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of
the city.
(Ord. 1103, passed 6-2-99; Am. Ord. 1112, passed 10-6-99; Am. Ord. 1239, passed
5-17-04)
§ 31.009 POLICE POWERS OF CITY OFFICERS.
   The Mayor, members of the City Council, members of the Fire Department, as
well as every member of the Police Department are declared to be conservators
of the peace with such powers to make arrests as are given to conservators of
the peace by statute.
(‘82 Code, § 2.44.090)
§ 31.010 DELIVERY OF BOOKS AND RECORDS TO CLERK OR TREASURER.
   Every officer of the city, upon termination of his or her office, for any
cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his or her successor in office all books and
records which may be the property of the city; and if no successor has been
appointed within one week after the termination of office, such property shall
be delivered either to the City Clerk or to the City Treasurer.
(‘82 Code, § 2.44.100)
§ 31.011 UNLAWFUL IMPERSONATION OF CITY OFFICER.
   It is unlawful for any person to impersonate any officer of the city without
lawful authority, and it shall also be unlawful for any person to interfere
with or hinder any officer or employee of the city while the officer or
employee is engaged in the duties of his or her office.
(‘82 Code, § 2.44.110)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 31.012 POLICY MANUAL.
   The City Council shall establish and maintain a personnel policy manual to
define the policies then in effect for all employees of the city. The manual
shall not constitute a contractual agreement between the city and the
employees. The manual shall serve as a guideline in dealing in a fair and
equitable manner with the employees. The manual may be adopted by a majority
vote of the City Council and may be amended by motion and majority vote of the
City Council. The City Council shall review each of the provisions of the
manual at least annually and shall make adjustments or amendments when deemed
necessary.
(Ord. 899, passed 4-4-89)
§ 31.013 CITY RETIREMENT FUND.
   (A)   The city elects to participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement
Fund, July 6, 1976.
(‘82 Code, § 2.48.010)
   (B)   The Clerk is directed to promptly file a certified copy of the
ordinance codified in this chapter with the Board of Trustees of the Illinois
Municipal Retirement Fund.
(‘82 Code, § 2.48.020)
(Ord. 703, passed - -76).
§ 31.014 OLD AGE AND SURVIVOR’S INSURANCE.
   (A)   Extension of benefits to eligible employees. It is declared to be the
policy and purpose of the city to extend to the eligible employees thereof the
benefits of the Federal Old Age and Survivors Insurance System as authorized by
the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto. In pursuance of such
policy, and for that purpose, the Mayor shall take such action as may be
required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations.
(‘82 Code, § 2.52.010)
   (B)   Execution of agreement with State Retirement System. The Mayor is
authorized and directed to execute an agreement with the State Employees'
Retirement System (Social Security Unit) to secure coverage of eligible
employees as provided in division (A) of this section.
(‘82 Code, § 2.52.020)
   (C)   Withholding authorization. Withholdings from salaries or wages of
employees for the purpose provided in division (A) of this section are
authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by
applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the
state agency in such amounts and at such times as are designated by state laws
and regulations.
(‘82 Code, § 2.52.030)
   (D)   Employer contributions and administrative expenses. Employer
contributions and administrative expense shall be paid to the state agency in
accordance with applicable state laws and regulations from amounts appropriated
for such purposes.
(‘82 Code, § 2.52.040)
   (E)   Maintenance of records. The Mayor shall maintain such records and
submit such reports as may be required by applicable state and federal laws or
regulations.
(‘82 Code, § 2.52.050)
(Ord. 469, passed - -53).
§ 31.015 SURETY BONDS.
   (A)   Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the city is required as a
prerequisite to exercising the duties of any office or position, or to the
issuance of any license or permit or for the exercise of any privilege, the
surety on such bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do
business in this state as a surety company, or an individual approved by the
Council as a surety.
   (B)   Whenever in the opinion of the Council additional surety or sureties
may be needed on any bond to indemnify the city against any loss or liability,
the Council may order new or additional sureties to be secured for such bond.
   (C)   If such new sureties or additional surety are not procured within ten
days from the time such order is transmitted to the principal on the bond, the
Council shall declare such bond to be void, and thereupon such principal, or
assignee, shall be deemed to have surrendered the privilege or position as a
condition of which the bond was required.
(‘82 Code, § 2.56.010)
CITY CLERK
§ 31.025 TERM OF OFFICE.
   The City Clerk shall be elected for a term of four years and shall serve
until his or her successor is elected and qualified as is provided by statute.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.010)
§ 31.026 BOND.
   Before entering upon his or her duties he or she shall give bond in such
amount and with such sureties as may be required by the Council, conditioned
upon the faithful performance of the duties of his or her office. He or she
shall take the oath of office as prescribed by statute and shall receive such
compensation as may be set from time to time by the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.020)
§ 31.027 SEALING AND ATTESTMENT OF CONTRACTS.
   The City Clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the city and all
licenses, permits and such other documents as may require this formality.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.030)
§ 31.028 DELIVERY OF FUNDS TO CITY TREASURER.
   The City Clerk shall turn over all money receive by him or her on behalf of
the city to the City Treasurer promptly on receipt of the same, and with such
money he or she shall give a statement as to the source thereof.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.040)
§ 31.029 FINANCIAL ACCOUNT REQUIREMENT.
   The City Clerk shall keep accounts showing all money received by him or her
on behalf of the city, the source thereof and the disposition thereof, and such
other accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.050)
§ 31.030 REGISTRY AND RECORDKEEPING REQUIREMENT.
   In addition to the record of ordinance and other records which the Clerk is
required by statute to keep, he or she shall keep a register of all licenses
and permits issued and the payments thereon, a record showing all of the
officers and regular employees of the city and such other records as may be
required by the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.060)
§ 31.031 CUSTODIAN OF CORPORATE SEAL.
   The Clerk shall be the custodian of the corporate seal and shall affix its
impression on documents whenever this is required.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.070)
§ 31.032 CUSTODIAN OF CITY DOCUMENTS.
   The Clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the city
which are not assigned to the custody of some other officer of the city by the
Mayor or Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.080)
§ 31.033 MAINTENANCE OF INDEX TO RECORDS AND DOCUMENTS.
   The Clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and
records kept by him or her so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be
had.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.090)
§ 31.034 ADDITIONAL DUTIES.
   In addition to the duties provided in this chapter, the Clerk shall act as
City Collector unless and until a separate City Collector is appointed as
provided by law, and he or she shall perform such other duties and functions as
may be required by statute or ordinance.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.100)
§ 31.035 VITAL STATISTICS REGISTRAR.
   (A)   The provision of the statutes shall be fully complied with by the City
Clerk in connection with vital statistics reports, and for that purpose the
City Clerk is made the registrar of vital statistics for the city.
   (B)   The City Clerk shall make sufficient copies of all such records so
that one complete set thereof may be retained and kept by the city.
(‘82 Code, § 2.12.110)
CITY TREASURER
§ 31.050 ELECTION.
   The City Treasurer shall be appointed by the Mayor, by and with the advice
and consent of the City Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.16.010) (Am. Ord. 912, passed 3-6-90)
§ 31.051 BOND.
   Before entering upon his or her duties, the Treasurer shall give bond in
such amount and with sureties as may be required by the Council, conditioned
upon the faithful performance of the duties of his or her office, and to
indemnify the city for any loss due to any neglect of his or her duty or
wrongful act on the part of the Treasurer. Such bond shall be not less than
three times the latest federal census population or any subsequent census
figure used for motor fuel tax purposes. This bond shall be filed with the City
Clerk. He or she shall take oath of office as provided by statute and shall
receive such compensation as may be from time to time set by the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.16.020)
§ 31.052 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The City Treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him or
her by statute or ordinance. He or she shall receive all money paid in to the
city, either directly from the person paying it or from the hands of such other
officer as may receive it, and he or she shall pay out only on vouchers or
orders properly signed by the Mayor and the City Clerk.
(‘82 Code, § 2.16.030)
§ 31.053 DEPOSIT OF CITY FUNDS.
   The Treasurer shall deposit the city funds in such depositories as may be
designated from time to time by the City Council as is provided by law, and he
or she shall keep the city money separate and distinct from his or her own and
shall not intermingle his or her own money with it or make private or personal
use of the city funds.
(‘82 Code, § 2.16.040)
§ 31.054 FINANCIAL RECORDKEEPING.
   The Treasurer shall keep records showing all money received by him or her,
the source from which it was received and the purpose for which it was paid
out; and he or she shall keep a record showing at all times the financial
status of the city.
(‘82 Code, § 2.16.050)
§ 31.055 MAINTENANCE OF BOOKS AND ACCOUNTS.
   The Treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by the
City Council and shall keep them in the manner required by the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.16.060)
§ 31.056 MONTHLY REPORT TO CITY COUNCIL.
   The Treasurer shall, at the ending of each and every month and on such other
dates and times as requested by the Mayor, render a complete account under oath
to the Mayor and City Council, or such officer of the city as may be designated
by the Mayor or majority vote of the Council, showing the state of the treasury
at the date of the account, the balance of money in the accounts of the city
and the amounts received and spent during the month or since the date of the
last report. The Treasurer shall also render an accounting of the present
balance of expended and unexpended amounts on each line item contained in the
annual budget of the city. This accounting of the present balance of line item
accounts shall be rendered monthly, on or before the 15th of the following
month. Each report shall be timely delivered to the City Clerk and shall be
filed with the Treasurer accounts in the city. The Treasurer shall annually,
within the time required by law or ordinance, complete and file with the City
Clerk a complete and detailed report of all receipts and expenditures of the
city, as shown by the records of the city, and in all of the transactions of
the Treasurer during the preceding fiscal year; and shall further reflect in
such report the state of the treasury at the close of the preceding fiscal year
which report shall be published as required by law by the City Clerk. Each
report filed by the City Treasurer shall be verified by the Treasurer under
oath.
(‘82 Code, § 2.16.070) (Am. Ord. 897, passed 4-4-89)
§ 31.057 REGISTRY OF WARRANTS, BOND, ORDERS AND VOUCHERS.
   The Treasurer shall keep a register of all warrants, bonds or orders filed
with him or her or paid by him or her and all vouchers as is required by
statute.
(‘82 Code, § 2.16.080)
CITY ATTORNEY
§ 31.070 OFFICE CREATED.
   There is created the office of City Attorney, an executive office of the
city. The City Attorney shall be appointed by the Mayor, by and with the advice
and consent of the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.20.010)
§ 31.071 LEGAL REPRESENTATIVE OF CITY.
   The City Attorney shall prosecute and defend all suits or actions at law or
equity to which the city may be a party, or in which it may be interested, or
which may be brought against, or by any officer of the city on behalf of the
city, or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the city.
(‘82 Code, § 2.20.020)
§ 31.072 LEGAL ADVISOR TO CITY.
   The City Attorney shall be the legal advisor of the city and shall render
advice on all legal questions affecting the city, whenever requested to do so
by any city official. Upon request by the Mayor or City Council, he or she
shall reduce such opinion to writing.
(‘82 Code, § 2.20.040)
§ 31.073 ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY.
   It is the duty of the City Attorney to see to the full enforcement of all
judgments or decrees rendered or entered in favor of the city and of all
similar interlocutory orders. It is his or her further duty to see to the
completion of all special assessment proceedings and condemnation proceedings.
(‘82 Code, § 2.20.030)
§ 31.074 SUPERVISION OF DRAFTING OF ORDINANCES AND DOCUMENTS.
   It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to supervise or draft the
phraseology of any contracts, leases or other documents or instruments to which
the city may be party and, upon request by the City Council, to draft
ordinances covering any subjects within the power of the city.
(‘82 Code, § 2.20.050)
CITY ADMINISTRATOR
§ 31.090 OFFICE CREATED.
   There is hereby created the City Administrator of the city.
(‘82 Code, § 2.22.010)
§ 31.091 APPOINTMENT.
   The City Administrator shall be appointed by the Mayor with advise and a
consent of the City Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.22.020)
§ 31.092 DUTIES.
   (A)   The City Administrator shall be in charge of overseeing the day to day
operations of the city employees and functions and such other specific duties
as the Mayor or the Council may from time to time assign.
   (B)   The City Administrator shall have the responsibility and duty to hire
al employees of the city without Mayor or City Council approval unless
otherwise specifically provided in this code.
(‘82 Code, § 2.22.030) (Am. Ord. 1574, passed 9-5-17)
CITY COLLECTOR
§ 31.110 OFFICE CREATED.
   The corporate authorities of the city hereby establish the office of City
Collector, an officer of the city. The City Collector shall hold office for one
year or until her or his successor is appointed and qualified. The City
Collector shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the
City Council. The City Collector shall be under the direction and supervision
of the City Administrator.
(Ord. 1275, passed 3-7-05)
§ 31.111 GENERAL DUTIES.
   It shall be the duty of the City Collector to supervise the collection and
receipt of all accounts due the city and to supervise the regular books and
records of the affairs of collection and to assist the City Treasurer as to
record keeping and such support related and incidental thereto. The City
Collector shall keep such records and perform such further duties as may be
required by state law or an ordinance of the city. The City Collector shall
also keep such books and accounts in the manner prescribed by the City
Administrator.
(Ord. 1275, passed 3-7-05)
§ 31.112 LICENSES.
   The City Collector shall issue all licenses and permits and provide forms
therefore, and shall collect and receive all fees paid or required for licenses
and permits in the absence of any provision to the contrary by any city
ordinance or state statute.
(Ord. 1275, passed 3-7-05)
§ 31.113 REPORTS.
   The City Collector shall make such reports of all money collected by the
City Collector and all books and accounts kept by the City Collector in such
manner and frequency as requested by the City Administrator. The City Collector
shall also provide such reports as may be required by state statute or a city
ordinance.
(Ord. 1275, passed 3-7-05)
§ 31.114 COMPENSATION.
   The City Collector shall receive such compensation as the City Council may
provide from time to time by ordinance.
(Ord. 1275, passed 3-7-05)
§ 31.115 BOND.
   The City Collector, before commencing his or her duties for the office,
shall give such bond in such amount with such sureties as may be required by
the City Council, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of
his or her office. He or she shall take the oath of office as prescribed by
state law.
(Ord. 1275, passed 3-7-05)

BOARD OF HEALTH
§ 32.01 OFFICE OF HEALTH OFFICER CREATED.
   There is created the office of health officer who shall be appointed by the
Mayor, with the advice and consent of the City Council, and who shall have the
powers of a police officer and a conservator of the peace.
(‘82 Code, § 2.24.010)
§ 32.02 POWERS AND DUTIES OF HEALTH OFFICER.
   The health officer shall examine all cases of contagious diseases arising in
the city and shall see to the enforcement of quarantine rules and determine the
time for raising the quarantine. He or she shall give the Mayor and Council
information and advice concerning the public health and shall perform such
other duties as may be assigned him or her by the Mayor and Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.24.030) (Am. Ord. 977, passed 7-6-93)
§ 32.03 VIOLATION.
   Any person violating or refusing any lawful order of the health officer or
destroying, mutilating or concealing any notice posted by or under the
authority of the health officer shall be subject to the penalties set forth in
§
10.99, and an offense shall be deemed to have been committed for each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(‘82 Code, § 2.24.080) (Am. Ord. 977, passed 7-6-93)
POLICE DEPARTMENT
§ 32.15 CREATION OF DEPARTMENT.
   There is created a Police Department, an executive department of the city.
The Police Department shall consist of the Police Chief who shall be
Superintendent of Police and Chief of the Police Department and of such number
of other police officers and patrol officers as may be provided from time to
time by the City Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.28.010)
§ 32.16 CHIEF OF POLICE.
   (A)   Office created. There is created the office of Chief of Police. The
Chief of Police is a hired position pursuant to the policy manual of the City
of Fulton and shall be an ‘at will’ employee. (‘82 Code, § 2.28.020)
   (B)   Powers and duties. 
      (1)   The Chief of Police shall be the keeper of the City Jail and shall
have care and custody of all persons incarcerated therein. He or she shall keep
such records and make such reports concerning the activities of his or her
Department as may be required by the Council or by statute.
      (2)   The Chief shall be responsible for the performance by the Police
Department of all of its functions and all persons who are members of the
Department shall serve subject to the orders of the Chief.
(‘82 Code, § 2.28.030) (Am. Ord. 1720, passed 6-12-23)
§ 32.17 CUSTODIAN OF STOLEN PROPERTY.
   The Chief of Police shall be the custodian of all lost, abandoned or stolen
property in the city.
(‘82 Code, § 2.28.060)
§ 32.18 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   It is the duty of every member of the Police Department to see to the
enforcement of all ordinances of the city and all statutes applicable thereto
and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and arrest all
violators thereof.
(‘82 Code, § 2.28.040)
§ 32.19 STANDARDS OF CONDUCT.
   It is the duty of every member of the Police Department to conduct himself
or herself in a proper and law abiding manner and at all times to avoid the use
of unnecessary force. Any member shall appear whenever necessary as a witness
in a prosecution for a violation of an ordinance, statute or federal law, and
no member shall retain any fee for service as a witness in any such suit or
action to which the city is a party; any fees paid for such services shall be
turned over to the City Treasurer.
(‘82 Code, § 2.28.050)
§ 32.20 SPECIAL POLICE OFFICERS.
   Any person of good character may be appointed special police officer by the
Mayor whenever in his or her opinion it may be necessary for the maintenance of
law and order within the city, provided, that except upon authorization by the
City Council, no such special police officer shall be entitled to compensation
nor shall such special police officer be considered an employee of the city.
Such special police officer shall be subject to all the rules of the Police
Department and may be deprived of his or her appointment at any time by the
Mayor or Chief of Police.
(‘82 Code, § 2.28.070)
§ 32.21 PART-TIME POLICE OFFICERS.
   (A)   Employment. The city may employ part-time police officers from time to
time as they deem necessary.
   (B)   Duties. A part-time police officer shall have all the responsibilities
of a full-time police officer and such specific duties as delineated in the
General Orders of the City of Fulton Police Department, but the number of hours
a part-time officer may work within a calendar year is restricted. Part-time
police officers shall not be assigned to supervise or direct full-time police
officers. Part-time police officers shall be trained in accordance with the
Illinois Police Training Act (ILCS Ch. 50, Act 705, §§ 1 et seq.) and the rules
and requirements of the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board.
   (C)   Hiring standards. Any person employed as a part-time police officer
must meet the following standards:
      (1)   Be of good moral character, sound health, physically and mentally
able to perform assigned duties.
      (2)   Be at least 21 years of age.
      (3)   Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate.
      (4)   Possess a valid State of Illinois driver's license.
      (5)   Possess no prior felony convictions.
      (6)   Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must have been
honorably discharged.
   (D)   Discipline. Part-time officers shall be under the disciplinary
jurisdiction of the Chief of Police. Part-time police officers serve at the
discretion of the city authorities and may be removed by the city authorities
at any time. Part-time police officers shall comply with all applicable rules
and General Orders issued by the Police Department.
(Ord. 1452, passed 5-21-12)
§ 32.22 COMMUNITY SERVICE OFFICER.
   (A)   Employment. The city may employ a Community Service Officer ("CSO").
   (B)   Duties. The Community Service Officer shall have the power to perform
routine and non-routine enforcement of the provisions of this code, including
but not limited to the following:
      (1)   Enforcement of code provisions related to existing buildings/
structures, properties, and vehicles;
      (2)   Assuring compliance with the provisions of this code related to
housing, zoning, health, and sanitation, and related ordinances;
      (3)   Effective January 1, 2025, performing the duties of the code
official under the International Property Maintenance Code, 2024 edition
(including Appendix A thereto and the 2024 Errata Sheet), as published by the
International Code Council, adopted by reference by ordinance and codified at §
150.24 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Fulton, or any other building
or maintenance code subsequently adopted by the city;
      (4)   Ensuring that new development and on-going land occupancy conforms
to applicable city and Whiteside County regulations regarding land use and
zoning, drainage and stormwater management, special flood hazard areas and
nuisance abasement;
      (5)   Hold the office and perform the duties of Zoning Enforcing Officer
under §
155.206, including but not limited to: the issuance of zoning use permits and
building permit requests, designing and maintaining a database of permit
records, reports, and handouts; and respond to zoning inquires by telephone and
in writing;
      (6)   Respond to parking problems;
      (7)   Assist police officers with traffic control during parades,
accidents, or other emergency scenes;
      (8)   Impound and transport lost pets to the local holding facility and
facilitate with the Whiteside County Animal Control for pickup and care of the
animal;
      (9)   Assist police officers with service calls that do not require a
sworn officer response, as needed;
      (10)   Report unsafe conditions and accidents to supervisors;
      (11)   Prepare correspondence and inspection reports, write narratives,
receive telephone calls, and respond to inquiries of a technical and non-
technical nature regarding codes, ordinances, and procedures; and
      (12)   Perform such other duties as requested or assigned by the Chief of
Police.
   (C)   Hiring standards. Any person employed as the Community Service Officer
must meet the following standards:
      (1)   Have completed two years of college with preferred courses in
building trades, code enforcement, or related field; or have two or more years
of related work experience; or have the equivalent of two years college and
related work experience;
      (2)   Possess a valid State of Illinois or Iowa driver's license;
      (3)   Obtain a certification as an International Code Council Property
Maintenance and Housing Inspector within 12 months of hire;
      (4)   Obtain a L.E.A.D.S. certification within the first 30 days of hire;
      (5)   Have AED/CPR/First Aid Training; and
      (6)   Have any other training deemed necessary by the Chief of Police or
Supervising Sergeant.
   (D)   Salary. The Community Service Officer shall perform his/her duties for
a salary annually fixed by the City Council.
   (E)   Supervision and discipline. The Community Service Officer shall be
under the disciplinary jurisdiction and supervision of the Chief of Police or
such other supervising officer as the Chief of Police shall determine from time
to time. The CSO shall serve at the discretion of the city authorities and may
be removed by the city authorities at any time. The CSO shall comply with all
applicable rules and General Orders issued by the Police Department.
(Ord. 1740, passed 6-10-24)
STREET DEPARTMENT
§ 32.60 CREATION OF DEPARTMENT.
   There is created the Department of Streets which shall consist of the
Superintendent of Streets who shall also be known as the Public Works Director
and shall be appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the City Council and
such other employees as may be hired by the City Administrator.
(‘82 Code, § 2.36.020) (Am. Ord. 1574, passed 9-5-17)
§ 32.61 SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS.
   (A)   Office created. There is created the office of Superintendent of
Streets, an executive office of the city, who shall be appointed by the Mayor,
with the advice and consent of the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.36.010)
   (B)   Powers and duties. The Superintendent of Streets shall have charge of
the improvement, repair, care, maintenance and clearing of all public streets,
avenues, alleys, highways, sidewalks and other public ways in the city, and he
or she shall perform such other duties as may be required of him or her by the
Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.36.030)
   (C)   Supervisory authority over employees and equipment. The Superintendent
of Streets shall have charge and supervision of all persons employed by the
city to labor on the streets, avenues and other public ways. He or she shall be
responsible for all trucks, tractors, graders and other equipment or apparatus
owned, purchased or leased by the city for use on the streets or alleys and
shall see that they are kept in good repair and are not misused or used without
proper permission.
(‘82 Code, § 2.36.040)
§ 32.62 UNLAWFUL USE OR DAMAGE OF EQUIPMENT.
   It is unlawful for any person to take, use, remove or otherwise disturb, or
to break, injure, deface or in any manner interfere with the working or use of
any truck, tractor, grader, mower or other equipment or apparatus belonging to
the city for use of the Department of Streets without permission of the Mayor
or City Council.
(‘82 Code, § 2.36.050)
Penalty, see § 10.99
WATER DEPARTMENT
§ 32.75 CREATION OF DEPARTMENT.
   There is created the Water Department of the city, which shall consist of
the Superintendent of Waterworks who shall also be known as the Public Works
Director and shall be appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the City
Council and such assistants or other personnel as may be hired by the City
Administrator.
(‘82 Code, § 2.40.020) (Am. Ord. 1574, passed 9-5-17)
§ 32.76 SUPERINTENDENT OF WATERWORKS.
   (A)   Office created. There is created the office of Superintendent of
Waterworks who shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of
the Council. He or she shall hold office for a term of two years and until his
or her successor is appointed and qualified. The Superintendent of Waterworks
shall be the executive officer of the Water Department and shall have charge of
the improvement, repair, care, maintenance and construction of all water mains,
hydrants, pumps, tanks, wells, sewers, apparatus, tools and equipment belonging
to the city for the care and maintenance of the water and sewer system of the
city, including the buildings and structures in connection therewith.
(‘82 Code, § 2.40.010)
   (B)   Powers and duties. It shall be the duty of the Superintendent of
Waterworks, subject to the order or approval of the Council, to:
      (1)   Manage and control all materials and things pertaining to the Water
Department;
      (2)   Employ and discharge all employees and workmen needed in the work
and service of the Water Department;
      (3)   Supervise and inspect all materials furnished and work done by and
for the water and sewer system of the city;
      (4)   Compel strict compliance with, and execution of, all contracts made
by or on behalf of the Water Department;
      (5)   Maintain and control all property of the Department of Water;
      (6)   Compel strict compliance with all rules, regulations and control of
the water and sewer system of the city; and
      (7)   Make complaint and institute prosecution for the violation of such
rules, regulations or ordinances.
(‘82 Code, § 2.40.030)
   (C)   Collection of rents and rates; maintenance of documents. The
Superintendent of Waterworks shall keep accurate maps or charts showing the
location and dimensions of all mains, hydrants, connections and other pertinent
facts and features of the sewer and water system of the city. He or she shall
also collect all rents or rates due the city by virtue of such water or sewer
service and shall keep such books, accounts and records as may be required by
the Council or by ordinance or statute and shall make such reports and
statements as may be required by the Council.   
(‘82 Code, § 2.40.040)
