CHAPTER 72: PARKING SCHEDULES
Schedule
   
I.   Two-hour parking limitation
   
II.   Morning parking prohibition
   
III.   Parking prohibited on specific streets
   
IV.   Restricted parking areas
   
V.   Resident parking area
   
VI.   Persons with disabilities parking
   
VII.   Restrictions on road tractors, truck tractors and semitrailers
   
VIII.   School bus loading zones
   
IX.   Parking in improvement area restricted
   
X.   Calendar parking and snow emergency routes
   
XI.   General parking restrictions
   
XII.   Definitions
   
XIII.   Penalty
SCHEDULE I. TWO-HOUR PARKING LIMITATION.
   (A)   Between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. of each day of the week
excepting Sunday, no vehicle shall be parked continuously in one parking space
for more than two hours on any portion of the following named streets and
avenues of the city:
      (1)   On Fourth Street between Ninth Avenue and Thirteenth Avenue.
      (2)   On Eleventh Avenue between Third Street and Fifth Street.
   (B)   Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this
schedule shall be fined not less than $25 per each offense.
(‘82 Code, § 10.24.060) (Ord. 516, passed - -60; Ord. 777, passed - -82; Am.
Ord. 1368, passed 4-7-08)
SCHEDULE II. MORNING PARKING PROHIBITION.
   (A)   No vehicles shall be parked on Fourth Street between Tenth Avenue and
Thirteenth Avenue and on Tenth Avenue between Third Street and Fourth Street
and on Eleventh Avenue between Third Street and Fifth Street between the hours
of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
   (B)   Any person, firm or corporation violating the provision of this
section shall be fined not less than $25 and no more than $750 for each
offense.
(‘82 Code, § 10.24.070) (Ord. 516, passed - -60; Ord. 778, passed - -82; Ord.
1251, passed 8-16-04; Am. Ord. 1368, passed 4-7-08)
SCHEDULE III. PARKING PROHIBITED ON SPECIFIC STREETS.
   (A)   Twelfth Street. Parking is banned on the east side of Twelfth Street
between Tenth Avenue and Eleventh Avenue. (‘82 Code, § 10.24.080)
   (B)   Ninth Street. Parking is banned on both sides of Ninth Street from
Tenth Avenue to Fourteenth Avenue. (‘82 Code, § 10.24.090)
   (C)   Fifteenth Avenue. Parking is prohibited on the south side of Fifteenth
Avenue from Fourth Street to Fourteenth Street. (‘82 Code, § 10.24.100)
   (D)   Eleventh Avenue. There shall be no parking on the north side of
Eleventh Avenue from Fourth Street east for 90 feet in the city. (‘82 Code, §
10.24.110)
   (E)   Fourteenth Avenue. Automobiles, trucks and other vehicles shall be
permitted to park on either side of Fourteenth Avenue (marked Illinois Route
136) between Fourth Street and Fourteenth Street within the corporate limits of
the city. Parking in this area shall be parallel parking only, diagonal parking
being expressly prohibited. Such parallel parking shall be executed that the
wheels of the vehicles nearest the cub shall not be farther away from the curb
than 12 inches. (‘82 Code, § 10.24.120)
   (F)   Tenth Avenue. Automobiles, trucks and other vehicles shall be
prohibited from parking along either side of Tenth Avenue between Fifth Street
and Ninth Street and between Twelfth Street and Illinois Highway 84 on the
roadway only. Parking in the other areas shall be parallel parking only,
diagonal parking being hereby expressly prohibited. Such parallel parking shall
be so executed that the wheels of the vehicles nearest the curb shall not be
farther away from the curb than 12 inches. Parking will not be permitted within
the limits of the intersections of First Street and Ninth Avenue and First
Street and Tenth Avenue as determined by the state from intersection studies.
(‘82 Code, § 10.24.130)
   (G)   Tenth Street. The portion of the east side of the 1300 block of Tenth
Street between 73 feet and 97 feet north of the northeast corner of the
intersection of Tenth Street and Fourteenth Avenue shall henceforth be a no
parking area, and signs shall be erected bearing said designation. (‘82 Code, §
10.24.140)
   (H)   Seventh Avenue. The portion of Seventh Avenue between Thirteenth
Street and Fourteenth Street in the city, and between the entrance and exit
driveway of the Fulton Elementary School, on the north side only, shall
henceforth be a no parking, standing or stopping area and signs shall be
erected bearing said designation. (‘82 Code, § 1.24.150)
   (I)   Thirteenth Street. Parking shall be prohibited on the east side of
Thirteenth Street from Eleventh Avenue to Twelfth Avenue.
   (J)   Seventeenth Street. Parking is hereby prohibited on both sides of
Seventeenth Street from the lift station of the Fulton Public Works Department
north to its intersection with Illinois Route 84.
   (K)   Twelfth Avenue. Parking is hereby prohibited on the north side of
Twelfth Avenue between its intersection with Fourth Street to its intersection
with Twelfth Street. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, parking
shall be permitted during any activity at the Immaculate Conception Church
building on the north side of Twelfth Avenue from its intersection with Sixth
Street to its intersection with Ninth Street.
   (L)   Seventh Avenue. No parking, standing or stopping from 7:30 a.m. to 3:
30 p.m. on school days - in the 1300 block of Seventh Avenue on the south side
only.
   (M) Thirteenth Street. No parking, standing or stopping from 7:30 a.m. to 3:
30 p.m. on school days - on Thirteenth Street in the 700 block of Thirteenth
Street on both sides.
   (N)   N. Twelfth Street. Parking is hereby prohibited on the east side of
Twelfth Street along that part thereof designated by a yellow painted curb and
between that part thereof designated by no parking signs.
   (O)   Eleventh Avenue. Parking is hereby prohibited on the north side of
Eleventh Avenue between its intersection with Fifth Street to its intersection
with Seventh Street, and between its intersection with Eighth Street to its
intersection with Tenth Street.
   (P)   Sixteenth Avenue. Parking is hereby prohibited on the north side of
Sixteenth Avenue between its intersection with Third Street to its intersection
with the public alley between Third Street and Fourth Street.
   (Q)   Fourth Street. Parking is hereby prohibited on the west side of Fourth
Street between its intersection with Sixteenth Avenue to its intersection with
Twenty-fourth Avenue.
   (R)   Parking is hereby prohibited on Seventh Avenue from the easterly line
of its intersection with Twelfth Street to a point 40 feet east from such
easterly line of Twelfth Street. No parking from here to corner signs shall be
erected.
   (S)   Parking is hereby prohibited on Seventh Street from the westerly line
of its intersection with Tenth Avenue to its intersection with Thirteenth
Avenue.
   (T)   Parking is hereby prohibited on Eleventh Avenue from the southerly
line of its intersection with Tenth Street to its intersection with Fourteenth
Street.
(Ord. 606, passed - -67; Ord. passed - -68; Ord. 634, passed - -71; Ord. 665,
passed - -73; Ord. 717, passed - -77; Ord. 1191, passed 8-20-02; Am. Ord. 1235,
passed 3-15-04; Am. Ord. 1262, passed 11-15-04; Am. Ord. 1295, passed 11-7-05;
Am. Ord. 1304, passed 3-6-06; Am. Ord. 1497, passed 12-2-13; Am. Ord. 1501,
passed 3-17-14; Am. Ord. 1596, passed 5-29-18; Am. Ord. 1602, passed 7-23-18;
Am. Ord. 1622, passed 3-25-19; Am. Ord. 1706, passed 9-12-22; Am. Ord. 1730,
passed 10-9-23)
SCHEDULE IV. RESTRICTED PARKING AREAS.
   (A)   The first 20 foot and the second 26 foot parking stalls south of Fifth
Avenue on the west side of Twelfth Street shall henceforth be restricted to 15
minutes maximum parking for the purpose of loading and unloading passengers on
Mondays through Fridays from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.
   (B)   The portion of Fifth Street between Tenth Avenue and Fourteenth
Avenue, on the west side only, shall henceforth be no parking any time, and
signs shall be erected bearing said designation.
   (C)   No motor vehicle shall be parked continuously in the city public
parking lot, immediately north of the City Hall building at 415 Eleventh
Avenue, for more than 24 hours.
   (D)   Eleven parking stalls on the south side of Twelfth Avenue, consisting
of the first six parking stalls immediately east of the intersection of Twelfth
Street and Twelfth Avenue, and the first five parking stalls immediately east
of the existing handicapped stall which is located immediately east of the six
parking stalls identified above, all 11 parking stalls being north of the
entrance door to the Fulton High School. The 11 parking stalls shall be
restricted only for parking for authorized staff of the Fulton High School and
for visitors to the Fulton High School during normal school hours. Such parking
stalls shall not be restricted except for normal school hours. No parking shall
be allowed during school hours except for such authorized staff and visitors.
   (E)   Parking shall be prohibited on the east side of 12th Street from its
intersection with 4th Avenue to its intersection with 7th Avenue, on each day
the Fulton school is in session for all or part of the day between the hours of
7:30 a.m. and 8:15 a.m. and between the hours of 2:30 p.m. and 3:15 p.m. The
city shall erect signs in such intervals and locations and content as the Chief
of Police deems appropriate.
   (F)   Eleventh Avenue. Parking shall be prohibited on the north side and the
south side of Eleventh Avenue between its intersection with Fourth Street to
its intersection with Third Street on each day from 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. from
November 1 each year to the following March 31 of the following calendar year.
The city shall erect signs at such intervals and locations as the Chief of
Police shall deem appropriate.
(Ord. 896, passed 4-4-89; Ord. 905, passed 8-1-89; Ord. 1055, passed 9-3-96;
Ord. 1333, passed 1-15-07; Am. Ord. 1490, passed 9-3-12; Am. Ord. 1622, passed
3-25-19)
SCHEDULE V. RESIDENT PARKING AREA.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any one except a resident to park a vehicle
in a resident parking area and during the times and hours stated in this
section.
   (B)   “Resident parking area” shall be defined as that part of the 1100 and
1200 block of Twelfth Avenue and the 1100 and 1200 block of Thirteenth Avenue
in the city that has been designated by action of a majority vote of the City
Council as a resident parking area at the request of an owner.
   (C)   No resident parking area shall be designated by the City Council
unless requested by the owner of a parcel of real estate in the defined area.
Such owner may make a request to the city to designate the parking area
contiguous to the real estate owned by the person making the request.
   (D)   The parking regulations under this section shall only apply and
parking shall be prohibited from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. each day that the
Riverbend High School is in session for all or part of a day.
   (E)   The city shall erect signs prohibiting parking of any vehicle in an
approved resident parking area informing the general public that parking is
restricted to the owner of the real estate, a resident of the real estate and
permitted guests of the owner and resident.
   (F)   The Police Department shall not be required to conduct regular routine
patrols of the resident parking area to enforce this schedule. It will be the
responsibility of the resident or owner of the real estate to notify the Police
Department that a vehicle may be parked in violation of this schedule. If a
parking violation ticket is issued, the resident or owner who reported the
violation shall be required to appear in court and testify if necessary in the
proper prosecution of the parking violation ticket. If the resident or owner
fails to appear in court and testify, the resident parking only designation for
that property shall be revoked immediately.
(Ord. 1075, passed 8-5-97)
SCHEDULE VI. PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES PARKING.
   (A)   Persons with disabilities parking places shall be at the following
locations within the city with specific locations to be determined by the Chief
of Police:
      (1)   The first parking stall on the west side of Fourth Street in the
1000 block, this being the southwest corner of the intersection of Tenth Avenue
and Fourth Street.
      (2)   The last parking stall on the west side of Fourth Street in the
1000 block, this being the northwest corner of the intersection of Eleventh
Avenue and Fourth Street.
      (3)   The last parking stall on the north side of Eleventh Avenue in the
400 block, this being the northeast corner of the intersection of Eleventh
Avenue and Fourth Street.
      (4)   One parallel parking stall located on Twelfth Street in the 300
block on the west side, 140 feet north of the intersection of Twelfth Street
and Fourth Avenue.
      (5)   Two parallel parking stalls located on Twelfth Avenue in the 700
block on the north side of Twelfth Avenue.
      (6)   One parking stall located on First Street in the 1000 block by the
public restrooms.
      (7)   Two parking stalls in the Heritage Canyon parking lot west of North
Fourth Street.
      (8)   Two parking stalls in front of the Gateway Faith Fellowship Church
at 701 Eleventh Avenue.
      (9)   One parking stall on the south side of the Fulton High School at
1207 Twelfth Street.
      (10)   One parking stall in the parking lot of the Fulton Marina at 1800
Fourth Street.
      (11)   One parking stall located on 16th Place in the 800 block for as
long as a person with disabilities is a resident of the building commonly known
as 821-827 16th Place in Fulton, Illinois. The Chief of Police shall have the
authority to remove the disability parking location in the event that no person
with disabilities is a resident of the building.
      (12)   One parking stall located on 12th Avenue in the 900 Block for as
long as a person with disabilities is a resident of the building commonly known
as 928 12th Avenue, Fulton, IL. The Chief of Police shall have the authority to
remove the disability parking location in the event that no person with
disabilities is a resident of 928 12th Avenue.
   (B)   Pursuant to the authority granted the city under § 11-208(d) in the
Illinois Vehicle Code, the city exercises its police power to prohibit the
unauthorized use of parking spaces reserved for persons with disabilities on
private property. All of the terms, conditions, requirements and penalties of
this Schedule VI shall apply the same to violations for parking places on
public property and parking places on private property. Persons with
disabilities parking places on private property shall be at the following
locations within the city with the specific locations to be approved by the
Chief of Police:

   (C)   These locations as determined by the City Council shall be designated
by proper signage as required by the Illinois Vehicle Code and the Illinois
Environmental Barriers Act, ILCS Ch. 410, Act 25, §§1 et seq.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for anyone to park in the designated area on
either public property or private property unless the motor vehicle bears
registration plates issued to a person with disabilities, as defined by ILCS
Ch. 625, Act 5, § 1-159.1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code as adopted by the city,
or by a special decal or device issued pursuant to ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 3-616
or pursuant to ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 11-1301.2 of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
as adopted by the city, or motor vehicle registered in another jurisdiction
upon which is displayed a registration plat, special decal or device issued by
the other jurisdiction designating the vehicle as operated by or for a person
with disabilities.
   (E)   Any person, firm, co-partnership, association or corporation found to
be an operator, driver or owner of a vehicle who has violated this schedule,
relating to persons with disabilities parking, shall be subject to a fine of
not less than $100 nor more than $250 for each offense. Violations of this
schedule as evidenced by a parking ticket in a form established by the Chief of
Police shall be punishable by fine as follows:
      (1)   One hundred dollars if paid on or before ten days from the date and
time of issuance of the parking ticket.
      (2)   One hundred fifty dollars if paid more than ten days after the date
and time of issuance of the parking ticket.
      (3)   If the fine in the amount set forth above shall not have been paid
to the office of the City Clerk or to the Police Department within 60 days from
the date and time of issuance of the parking ticket, a complaint shall be filed
in the Circuit Court of Whiteside County and a notice to appeal shall be issued
to the person in whose name the offending vehicle is registered, notifying that
person to appear before the Circuit Court to answer the charge of violating
this schedule. The minimum fine for each offense upon a finding of guilty or
plea of guilty before the Circuit Court on a charge under this section shall be
$250. Proceedings shall follow as in all other ordinance violations of the
city.
(Ord. 937, passed 6-5-91; Am. Ord. 964, passed 8-4-92; Am. Ord. 1020, passed 3-
8-95; Am. Ord. 1052-A, passed 7-2-96; Am. Ord. 1371, passed 5-19-08; Am. Ord.
1424, passed 1-17-11; Am. Ord. 1512, passed 10-6-14; Am. Ord. 1583, passed 2-
12-18)

SCHEDULE VIII. SCHOOL BUS LOADING ZONES.
   Automobiles, trucks and all other vehicles except school buses shall be
prohibited from parking on the north side of Thirteenth Avenue between the
intersection of Twelfth Street and the intersection of Thirteenth Street,
between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. on
school days in the city. Signs shall be erected bearing such prohibition and
indicating a school bus loading zone.
(Ord. 1037, passed 10-3-95; Am. Ord. 1062, passed 11-5-96)
SCHEDULE IX. PARKING IN IMPROVEMENT AREA RESTRICTED.
   Automobiles, trucks and other vehicles shall be prohibited from parking on
Fourth Street and Fourteenth Avenue within the limits of this improvement.
Parking will not be permitted within the limits of intersections as determined
by the state from intersection studies.
(Ord. 1080, passed 12-2-97)
SCHEDULE X. CALENDAR PARKING AND SNOW EMERGENCY ROUTES.
   (A)   Applicability of schedule.
      (1)   The term "street" as used herein shall include streets, alleys,
city property and public rights-of-way in the city.
      (2)   The provisions of this schedule shall apply when a snow or other
emergency declaration has been issued by the Director of Public Works or his or
her designee.
      (3)   Nothing in this schedule shall be construed to permit parking on
streets where such parking is otherwise prohibited.
      (4)   The provisions of this schedule shall be in effect during a snow or
other emergency as provided in this schedule.
      (5)   The parking restrictions imposed by this schedule shall terminate
block by block as soon as the accumulated snow has been removed from the full
width of the street, or at the direction of the director of public works or his
or her designee in the event of other emergency declaration or order.
   (B)   Declaration of snow or other emergency and notification to the public.
      (1)   Whenever snow, freezing rain, sleet, snowdrifts or other natural
phenomena create, or are likely to create, hazardous road conditions, or road
conditions impeding, or likely to impede, the free movement of fire, health,
police, emergency or other vehicular traffic vital to the health, safety and
welfare of the city: the Director of Public Works, or his or her designee,
shall have the authority to declare a snow or other emergency. Such snow
emergency shall exist until the snow has been removed from the full width of
the street or until the director of public works declares the snow or other
emergency is over.
      (2)   The Director of Public Works shall request the cooperation of the
local news media to announce the declaration of a snow emergency. The
provisions of this schedule prohibiting parking on parts of streets, or
designated snow route streets, shall be effective at a specific time to be
stated in the announcement, not less than one hour after the initial
announcement, and such notice shall constitute notice to the general public of
the declaration of the emergency.
   (C)   Posting of snow or other emergency signs. Signs shall be posted on
primary roads at or near those points of intersection with the corporate
boundaries of the city stating, "Restricted Parking During Snowfall Over 2 in.
or Other Emergencies: Calendar Parking in Effect Until Snow Has Been Removed
from the Full Width of the Street, or ordered by City."
   (D)   Parking restrictions during snow or other emergencies. After the
effective time specified in the declaration of a snow or other emergency, it is
unlawful for any person to obstruct the orderly removal of snow or other debris
from streets by parking or otherwise leaving unattended any motor vehicle upon:
      (1)   Snow routes. Any street which has been designated as a snow route.
The parking restrictions of this schedule shall terminate block by block as
soon as the accumulated snow has been removed from the full width of the
street;
      (2)   All other city streets. During the time of a snow or other
emergency, no person shall leave parked or standing any motor vehicle on an
even-numbered address side of a street within the city on an odd-numbered day
of the month. Nor shall any such vehicle be parked or allowed to stand on the
odd-numbered side of a street within the city on an even-numbered day of the
month. For purposes of this schedule, odd- and even-numbered days shall be
considered as beginning at 7:00 a.m.
   (E)   Designation of snow routes. No parking shall be permitted on all snow
emergency routes until snow has been plowed to the outside edges of the
traveled portions of the street rights-of-way. emergency snow routes shall be
designated by blue and white "snow route" signs. The following streets are
designated as snow emergency routes:
      (1)   Third Avenue;
      (2)   Tenth Avenue;
      (3)   Fourteenth Avenue;
      (4)   Sixteenth Avenue;
      (5)   Nineteenth Avenue;
      (6)   Twenty-fourth Avenue;
      (7)   Fourth Street;
      (8)   Fifth Street from Fourteenth Avenue north to Tenth Avenue;
      (9)   Sixth Street;
      (10)   Ninth Street;
      (11)   Twelfth Street;
      (12)   Route to Senior Housing Home (from Tenth Avenue north on Sixteenth
Street to Ninth Avenue east to Seventeenth Street north to Eighth Avenue and
Harbor Crest).
   (F)   Towing of vehicles. During the time of a snow or other emergency, the
Chief of Police or his or her designee may direct those vehicles parked in
violation of this schedule be removed, and that the owner of any vehicle so
removed shall be responsible for all towing and storage costs. Neither the city
nor the towing service shall be liable for any damage to any vehicle, device or
property so removed.
   (G)   Termination of snow or other emergency. Whenever the Director of
Public Works shall find that the conditions which gave rise to the snow or
other emergency no longer exist, he or she is authorized to declare the
termination of the snow emergency, effective immediately upon announcement.
When the snow or other emergency is terminated, it shall then be lawful to park
on streets in accordance with the regular parking provisions. The Director of
Public Works shall request the cooperation of the local media to announce the
termination of the snow or other emergency.
   (H)   Violation: penalty designated. Any violation of this schedule shall be
subject to a fine in the amount provided in the city penalty §
94.99 plus any towing charges and storage charges incurred by the city. Any
vehicle removed at the direction of the Chief of Police, or his or her designee
is subject to administrative penalty of the City of Fulton, not to exceed $100.
For purposes of prosecution under this schedule, if a vehicle is found parked
or left unattended in violation of the provisions of this schedule, the
registered owner thereof shall be responsible for said violation.
(‘82 Code, § 10.28.020) (Ord. 742, passed - -79; Am. Ord. 1716, passed 3-27-23)
SCHEDULE XI. GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   It is unlawful to permit any vehicle, except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other vehicles, or in compliance with the direction of a police
officer or traffic control signal, to stand in any of the following places:
      (1)   In any crosswalk;
      (2)   In any intersection;
      (3)   Upon any bridge or viaduct or the approach thereto;
      (4)   Within 20 feet of any intersection;
      (5)   At any curb within 15 feet of a fire hydrant;
      (6)   At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway;
      (7)   Within 20 feet of the entrance to any fire department station, and
on the side of the street opposite the entrance to the station within 75 feet
of the entrance;
      (8)   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge of
a curb or street; or
      (9)   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
   (B)   No vehicle shall be parked with the left side thereof at the curb, and
it is unlawful to stand or park any vehicle in any street other than parallel
with the curb and with the two right wheels within 12 inches of the regularly
established curb line, except upon those streets which have been marked for
angle parking upon which vehicles shall be parked within the lines and at the
angle indicated by such marks.
   (C)   It is unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of
displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street for the
purpose of vending or peddling merchandise from such vehicle.
   (D)   During the times specified in this section it is unlawful for the
driver of any vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for longer than is necessary
to load or unload passengers, and in no event longer than five minutes, and for
the driver to stand any freight vehicle for a period of time longer than is
necessary to load, unload or deliver materials, and in no event longer than 15
minutes in any public alley, during any hour of the day or night.
   (E)   No motor vehicle or vehicle or trailer or watercraft shall be
continuously in one place on any street, avenue or alley in the city for more
than 72 hours. The term STREET, AVENUE and ALLEY shall be defined to include
the entire public right of way and all property dedicated for public use and
not only the paved portion used for roadway purposes. The term MOTOR VEHICLE,
VEHICLE AND TRAILER shall be the same as defined in the Illinois Vehicle Code
adopted by reference in §
70.01 of this code. The term WATERCRAFT shall be as defined in Chapter 625,
Illinois Compiled Statutes, Act 5 entitled Boat Registration and Safety Act.
(Ord. 1183, passed 4-16-02; Am. Ord. 1564, passed 5-15-17)
SCHEDULE XII. DEFINITIONS.
   The word VEHICLE, when used in this chapter, shall mean every devise, in,
upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon
a street, alley or highway, or requiring a certificate of title under the laws
of the state, except devices moved by human power, devices used exclusively
upon stationary rails or tracks and snowmobiles as defined in the Illinois
Snowmobile Registration and Safety Act.
(Ord. 1318, passed 8-21-06)
SCHEDULE XIII. PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter
for which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon conviction,
be subject to a fine of not less than $25 nor more than $750 for each offense.
A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day during which a
violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 1368, passed 4-7-08)
CHAPTER 73: NON-HIGHWAY VEHICLE OPERATION ON CITY STREETS
Publisher's Note: This Chapter has been AMENDED by new legislation (Ord. 1763,
adopted 6-9-2025). The text of the amendment will be incorporated below when
the ordinance is codified.
Section
   
73.01   Definitions
   
73.02   Requirements
   
73.03   Permits
   
73.04   Signage
 
   
73.99   Penalty
§ 73.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY STREETS. The portion of any street, alley or roadway, improved,
designed, or ordinarily used for vehicle travel or parking, located within the
boundaries of the City of Fulton, Illinois, excluding any highway under the
jurisdiction of the State of Illinois or County of Whiteside.
   CODE. The Illinois Vehicle Code in ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5.
   NON-HIGHWAY VEHICLES. A motor vehicle authorized by state law in ILCS Ch.
625, Act 5, § 11-1426.1 and defined in the Code as follows:
      (1)   ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLE. Any motorized off-highway device designed to
travel primarily off-highway, 50 inches or less in width, having a
manufacturer's dry weight of 1,500 pounds or less, traveling on three or more
non-highway tires, designed with a seat or saddle for operator use, and
handlebars or steering wheel for steering control, except equipment such as
lawnmowers.
      (2)   GOLF CART. A vehicle specifically designed and intended for the
purposes of transporting one or more persons and their golf clubs or
maintenance equipment while engaged in the playing of golf, supervising the
play of golf, or maintaining the condition of the grounds on a public or
private golf course.
      (3)   OFF-HIGHWAY MOTORCYCLE. Any motorized device designed to travel
primarily off-highway on two wheels, having a seat or saddle for the use of the
operator, upon or by which any person, persons or property may be transported
or drawn.
      (4)   RECREATIONAL OFF-HIGHWAY VEHICLE. Any motorized off-highway device
designed to travel primarily off-highway, 64 inches or less in width, having a
manufacturer's dry weight of 2,000 pounds or less, traveling on four or more
non-highway tires, designed with a non-straddle seat and a steering wheel for
steering control, except equipment such as lawnmowers.
(Ord. 1677, passed 4-26-21)
§ 73.02 REQUIREMENTS.
   A person may operate a non-highway vehicle on the city streets if the person
and non-highway vehicle comply with all the following requirements and
conditions:
   (A)   All non-highway vehicles shall be certified by the Chief of Police
after inspection by a city designated representative. If the vehicle is
certified by the Chief, a permit shall be issued by the Chief evidenced by a
decal which shall be affixed to the rear of the vehicle.
   (B)   All permits shall expire on July 1 of each year, unless renewed.
   (C)   Comply with the published "Rules Concerning Operation of Non-Highway
Vehicles on City Streets" as determined by the City Council.
   (D)   Must have current, valid ddwr's license issued to the operator.
   (E)   No non-highway vehicles shall be operated on any city street unless
equipped with all of the following in good operating condition:
      (1)   Brakes and brake lights;
      (2)   Turn signals;
      (3)   Steering wheel apparatus;
      (4)   Tires;
      (5)   Rearview mirror;
      (6)   "Slow Moving Vehicle" emblem on the rear of the vehicle as required
by ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 12-709;
      (7)   Headlight that emits a white light visible from a distance of 500
feet to the front which will illuminate when in operation;
      (8)   Tail lamp that emits red light visible from at least 100 feet from
the rear which must illuminate when in operation;
      (9)   Red reflectorized warning devices on each rear side and one in the
center rear of the vehicle; and
      (10)   The operator and passenger shall not use the vehicle in an unsafe
manner.
   (F)   Comply with the mandatory insurance requirements under ILCS Ch. 625,
Act 5, §§ 6-100 et seq.
   (G)   Any other applicable requirements of the Code as may be amended from
time to time.
   (H)   Yield to the right-of-way to all other vehicles and pedestrians at all
times.
   (I)   All occupants of a non-highway vehicle between the ages of three years
and 18 years of age shall be restrained with a seat belt at all times while the
non-highway vehicle is moving in any direction. Furthermore, all occupants
under the age of three years shall be restrained in a car seat and the car seat
shall be attached to the non-llighway vehicle by a seatbelt.
   (J)   Obey all traffic laws of the State of Illinois and the City of Fulton.
   (K)   All operators of a non-highway vehicle shall be 18 years of age or
older.
   (L)   Operation is prohibited on sidewallcs or city parks other than parking
areas.
   (M)   A non-highway vehicle may not be operated in excess of 25 miles per
hour or the posted speed limit, whichever is lower.
   (N)   (1)   Non-highway vehicles may not operate on 14th Avenue (also known
as Illinois Route 136) except to cross 14th Avenue at its intersection with 4th
Street, 9th Street and 14th Street and shall only cross 14th Avenue at an angle
of approximately 90 degrees to the direction of Route 136 and not at any other
intersections in the city, is brought to a complete stop before attempting a
crossing and the operator shall yield the right-of-way to all pedestrian and
vehicle traffic which constitutes a hazard.
      (2)   Non-highway vehicles may not cross 10th Avenue except at its
intersection with 9th Street and 14th Street.
   (O)   The operator and the non-highway vehicle shall be subject to
inspection by the Chief of Police or a representative of the Police Department
at any time.
   (P)   A non-highway vehicle shall not be operated from 10:00 p.m. to the
following morning at sunrise and shall not be operated during inclement weather
or when visibility is impaired by weather, smoke, fog or other condition, or at
any time when light is insufficient to clearly see persons or vehicles on the
city streets at a distance of 500 feet, in an unsafe or reckless manner, or in
violation of any provision of this chapter.
   (Q)   The operator and passengers shall not use or operate the vehicle in an
unsafe manner as determined by the Fulton Police Department.
   (R)   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, a non-highway vehicle
shall not be allowed to operate on the following streets, avenues and public
places in the city at any time whatsoever:
      (1)   The entire length of 4th Street south of its intersection with 24th
Avenue and that part of 4th Street between its intersection with 13th Avenue
and 10th Avenue. Fourth Street shall not be crossed at its intersection with
12th Avenue or its intersection with 11th Avenue;
      (2)   The entire length of 14th, Avenue except for that part of 14th
Avenue between its intersection with 14th Street and its intersection with 17th
Street;
      (3)   The entire length of 31st Avenue;
      (4)   The entire length of 10th Avenue;
      (5)   The entire length of 12th Street from its intersection with 14th
Avenue to its intersection with 3rd Avenue;
      (6)   The entire length of Illinois Route 84;
      (7)   The entire length of US Highway 30; and
      (8)   The entire length of all bicycle and pedestrian paths and pathways
in the city on any public property and on public areas intended for use by
pedestrians and bicycles.
(Ord. 1677, passed 4-26-21)
§ 73.03 PERMITS.
   (A)   No person shall operate a non-highway vehicle without first obtaining
a permit from the Chief of Police as provided herein. Permits shall be granted
for a period of one year from July 1 to June 30. The cost of a permit shall be
$100 for each vehicle for a full year and pro-rated to $50 for half year or
less. Insurance coverage shall be verified by the police department when
issuing or renewing a permit.
   (B)   Every application for a permit shall be made on a form supplied by the
city and shall contain the following information:
      (1)   Name and address of applicant;
      (2)   Name of liability insurance carrier and policy number;
      (3)   The serial number, make, model and description of the non-highway
vehicle;
      (4)   Signed waiver of liability by applicant releasing the City of
Fulton and its officers, Mayor, City Council and employees and agreeing to
indemnify and hold the city harmless from any and all future claims resulting
from the operation of their non-highway vehicle on the city streets;
      (5)   Photocopy of applicable liability insurance coverage card for the
vehicle to be operated pursuant ta the permit;
      (6)   Such other information as the city may require;
   (C)   No permit shall be granted unless the following conditions are met:
      (1)   The vehicle must be inspected by the city Chief of Police (or
designee) to ensure that the non-highway vehicle is safe to operate an city
streets and is in compliance with this chapter and the Code;
      (2)   A physically handicapped applicant must submit a certificate signed
by a physician, certifying that the applicant is able to safely operate a
qualified non-highway vehicle on city streets;
      (3)   The applicant must provide evidence of insurance in compliance with
the provisions of all applicable Illinois Statutes regarding minimum liability
insurance for passenger motor vehicles to be operated on the roads of the State
of Illinois.
   (D)   The city may suspend or revoke a permit granted hereunder upon a
determination by the Chief of Police in his or her sole discretion, that the
holder thereof has violated any provision of this Chapter or the Code or that
the holder cannot safely operate a qualified non-highway vehicle on city
streets.
(Ord. 1677, passed 4-26-21)
§ 73.04 SIGNAGE.
   The city shall erect appropriate signs required by any applicable law or
regulation including the state manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices and
such other signs the city determines appropriate. Operators shall obey all
signage.
(Ord. 1677, passed 4-26-21)
§ 73.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any provisions of this chapter or any person who
operates a non-highway vehicle in violation of any provisions of this chapter
shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $750 for each
offense. Any second or subsequent offense shall result in a revocation of the
authority to operate a non-highway vehicle on city streets for a period of not
less than three years. The length of the revocation shall be determined by the
City Council. In addition, all court costs, which shall include all costs
incurred by the city in prosecuting the case, shall be recoverable from anyone
convicted of a violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 1677, passed 4-26-21)

CHAPTER 90: FIREWORKS; EXPLOSIVES
Section

FIREWORKS
§ 90.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purposes of this subchapter, FIREWORKS means and includes any
explosive composition or any substance or combinations of substances or article
prepared for the purpose of producing an audible or visible effect by
explosion, combustion, deflagration or detonation and shall include blank
cartridges, toy cannons in which explosives are used, the type of balloons
which require fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes,
skyrockets, Roman candles, bombs or other fireworks of like construction and
any fireworks containing any explosive compound, or any tablet or other device
containing any explosive compound, or any tablet or other device containing any
explosive substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual
effects; provided, however, that the term shall not include snake or glow worm
pellets; smoke devices; trick noisemakers known as “party poppers”, “booby
traps”, “snappers”, “trickmatches”, “cigarette loads” and “auto burglar
alarms”; sparklers, toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns or other like devices in
which paper or plastic caps containing twenty-five hundredths grains or less of
explosive compound are used, providing they are so constructed that the hand
cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion, and toy
pistol paper or plastic caps which contain less than twenty-five hundredths
grains of explosive mixture, the sale and use of which shall be permitted at
all times.
(‘82 Code, § 8.24.010)
Statutory reference:
   Fireworks Regulation Act, ILCS Ch. 425, Act 30, §§ 1 et seq.
   Pyrotechnic Use Act, ILCS Ch. 425, Act 35, §§ 1 et seq.
§ 90.02 SALE OR USE OF FIREWORKS RESTRICTED.
   Except as provided in this subchapter, it is unlawful for any person, firm
or corporation to offer or expose for sale, sell, use or explode any fireworks.
(‘82 Code, § 8.24.020)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 90.03 CITY COUNCIL REQUIREMENT.
   Permission for public displays of fireworks may be granted by the City
Council to any group of three or more adult individuals.
(‘82 Code, § 8.24.030)
§ 90.04 PERMIT APPLICATION PROCEDURE.
   Applications for such permits shall be made to the City Clerk and shall
state the group desiring to make such public display and the premises upon
which such display is to be set off and the premises upon which they are to be
stored previous to such display. All of such storage, exhibition and display
shall be under the supervision of the Chief of the Fire Department or some
other person designated by him or her.
(‘82 Code, § 8.24.040)
Penalty, see § 10.99
EXPLOSIVES
§ 90.20 STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES; PERMIT REQUIREMENT.
   It is unlawful to keep or store any dynamite, black powder, gunpowder or
guncotton in excess of five pounds in any one building or on any one premises
within the city without a permit from the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 8.20.010)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 90.21 PERMIT APPLICATION; BOND.
   (A)   Applications for such permits shall be made to the City Clerk and
shall be accompanied by a statement showing the amount of such explosives
intended to be kept, the kind of explosive intended to be kept, the premises
upon which such explosive is to be kept, the purpose for which it is to be used
and a statement that all such explosives are to be stored or kept in accordance
with all of the rules and regulations laid down by the State Fire Marshal with
regard to such explosives.
   (B)   The application shall be further accompanied by a bond or indemnity
policy in the sum of $10,000 with corporate surety, conditioned upon the
compliance of the applicant with all of the provisions of this chapter and to
hold the city harmless from any loss, damage or liability by reason of the
storage or use of such explosives.
(‘82 Code, § 8.20.020)
§ 90.22 STORAGE OF NITROGLYCERINE OR TNT; RESTRICTIONS.
   It is unlawful to keep, store or use any nitroglycerine or the explosive
commonly known as TNT in the city in any quantity except for medicinal or
laboratory purposes, and for such purpose no more than one-half pound shall be
kept or stored in any one building.
(‘82 Code, § 8.20.030)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 90.23 STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES; REGULATORY AUTHORITY.
   All explosives kept or stored in the city, regardless of the amount or kind
of such explosive, shall be kept and stored in accordance with the rules and
regulations laid down and enforced by the State Marshal with regard thereto.
(‘82 Code, § 8.20.040)
Penalty, see § 10.99
CHAPTER 91: HEALTH AND SAFETY

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 91.01 MILK.
   (A)   Pasteurized milk defined.  
      (1)   For the purposes of this section, "pasteurized milk" means milk
subjected to one of the following processes:
         (a)   The process of heating every particle of milk to at least 145°F
and holding at such temperature for at least 30 minutes;
         (b)   Heating every particle of milk to at least 161°F and holding
such temperature at least 15 seconds.
      (2)   Either method shall be carried out only in apparatus approved by
the State Department of Health and properly operated. Provided, nothing in this
definition shall be considered as disbarring any other process which has been
demonstrated to be equally efficient and is approved by the Department of
Health.
(‘82 Code, § 8.08.010)
   (B)   Sale of unpasteurized milk prohibited. No person, firm, association or
corporation shall sell or distribute, offer to sell or distribute or possess
with intent to sell or distribute any milk for human use or consumption in this
city unless such milk has been pasteurized.
(‘82 Code, § 8.08.020)
(Ord. 493, passed - -57)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 91.02 PLANTS AND WEEDS.
   (A)   Nuisance weeds. Any weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle,
cockleburr or any other weeds of like kind found growing in any lot or tract of
land in the city are a nuisance, and it is unlawful to permit any such weeds to
grow or remain in any such place.
(‘82 Code, § 8.28.010)
   (B)   Weeds, grass or plants; height restrictions. It is unlawful to permit
any weeds, grass or plants other than trees, bushes, flowers or other
ornamental plants to grow to a height exceeding eight inches anywhere within
the city, any such plants exceeding such height are a nuisance.
(‘82 Code, § 8.28.020)
   (C)   Abatement procedure. 
      (1)   It is the duty of the health officer to serve or cause to be served
a notice upon the owner or occupant of any premises on which weeds or plants
are permitted to grow in violation of the provisions of this section and to
demand the abatement of such nuisances within ten days.
      (2)   If such person does not proceed to abate such nuisance within ten
days, the health officer shall proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an
account of the expenses of such abatement, and such expense shall be charged to
and paid by such owner or occupant.
(‘82 Code, § 8.28.030)
   (D)   Exceptions. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this section
or any other section of this Code, a committee comprised of the Public Works
Director, City Administrator and one Alderman to be appointed by the Mayor to
serve for the time set forth in the motion, may determine in their sole
discretion by majority vote, to grant an exception for certain areas of the
city to the requirements of this section. Any exceptions granted by a majority
vote of the committee shall be set forth in writing with sufficient clarity to
identify the location of the excepted area and all terms and conditions of the
exception as may be determined at the sole discretion of the committee. A copy
of the written exception shall be provided to the owner or owners of the real
estate included in the exception and shall be available at City Hall for
inspection by the general public. The City Council may by majority vote,
reverse a decision of the committee to grant or deny an exception under this
section.
(Ord. 1435, passed 9-6-11)
Penalty, see §
91.99
§ 91.03 FLOOD CONTROL SYSTEM.
   (A)   Misuse prohibited. It is unlawful to damage, interfere with or misuse
the city flood control system, as defined in division (B) of this section, so
as to hinder the safe and proper operation of the system or cause unnecessary
costs to the city.
(‘82 Code, § 8.60.010)
   (B)   System defined. "Flood control system" means all structures and
property, including flood protection levies, pumping stations, drainage
structures, ditches, culverts and right-of-way markers that are or will be
established, constructed or placed for the purpose of controlling flood waters
in the corporate limits of the city.
(‘82 Code, § 8.60.020)
   (C)   Prohibited acts. The following acts shall be considered misusing,
damaging or interfering with the flood control system and are prohibited:
      (1)   The driving or operating of any motorized vehicle on any part of
any flood control levy or embankment thereof, except as authorized by an
officer of the city for the purpose of maintenance, repair or other
nondestructive activity;
      (2)   The abandoning or storing of any motorized vehicle or part thereof
on any flood control system property;
      (3)   The removal, destruction or defacing of any right-of-way marker,
drainage structure, building, gate or fence that exists as a part of the flood
control system;
      (4)   The depositing of any items such as junk, rubbish, ground, brush,
trees, boards, tires and so forth, on any levy or in any drainage ditch of the
flood control system;
      (5)   The removal or displacement of any ground, rock or sod from any
levy or drainage ditch without the authorization of the Mayor or City
Superintendent.
(‘82 Code, § 8.60.030)
(Ord. 737, passed - -79)
FOOD SERVICES ESTABLISHMENTS
§ 91.15 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   FOOD. Any condiment, nutrient or aliment, whether vegetable, animal or
mineral, either raw or processed or partly raw and partly processed, which is
fit for or used for human consumption. Additionally, FOOD means and includes
any beverage intended for human consumption.
   FOOD DEALER. Any person, firm or corporation which shall sell or offer for
sale, or keep or store for the purpose of sale or offering for sale such food.
(‘82 Code, § 8.04.010)
§ 91.16 SALE OF UNWHOLESOME FOOD PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall sell, offer for sale, keep or store any
food of any kind which is spoiled, tainted or is unwholesome or unfit for human
consumption for any reason.
(‘82 Code, § 8.04.020)
Penalty, see § 91.99
§ 91.17 SALE OF ADULTERATED FOOD PROHIBITED.
   It is unlawful to sell, offer for sale or keep or store for such purpose any
food or drink which has been adulterated by any material harmful in any way or
which does not comply with the state statutes governing the same.
(‘82 Code, § 8.04.030)
Penalty, see § 91.99
§ 91.18 SANITARY PREMISES REQUIREMENTS.
   Premises used for the sale of food or drink intended for human consumption
shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and it is unlawful to permit
any accumulation of refuse or waste of any kind therein or thereon for more
than 24 hours. It is unlawful to permit any decaying plant or animal matter to
remain on such premises at all.
(‘82 Code, § 8.04.040)
Penalty, see § 91.99
§ 91.19 UTENSIL STERILIZATION.
   Utensils for personal use in all places serving food or drink to the public
shall be thoroughly cleaned and sterilized after each such usage.
(‘82 Code, § 8.04.050)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 91.20 ADDITIONAL SANITARY REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   All premises used in the sale or storage of food or drink intended for
human consumption shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
   (B)   It is unlawful to permit any person who is afflicted with any
contagious, infectious or epidemic disease to handle any food or drink intended
for sale.
   (C)   Premises shall be kept free of flies and vermin of all kinds.
(‘82 Code, § 8.04.060)
Penalty, see § 91.99
§ 91.21 PERSONAL HYGIENE OF FOOD HANDLERS.
   All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food or drink
intended for human consumption shall keep themselves and their clothes clean,
and it is unlawful to permit any person afflicted with any contagious,
infectious or venereal disease to handle any food intended for sale for human
consumption.
(‘82 Code, § 8.04.070)
Penalty, see § 91.99
CONTAGIOUS DISEASES
§ 91.35 PHYSICIAN REPORT REQUIREMENT.
   (A)   Every physician called in to treat or care for any contagious or
epidemic disease shall report the same within 24 hours to the health officer.
   (B)   In case no physician is in attendance, it shall be the duty of the
person having charge of or in care of such person to make a report within 24
hours from the time the disease is recognized.
(‘82 Code, § 8.12.010)
§ 91.36 HEALTH OFFICER; QUARANTINE POWERS.
   The health officer shall have charge of the enforcement of rules of
quarantine. He or she shall have the power and authority to place any premises
in which a contagious or epidemic disease occurs under quarantine, and he or
she shall determine when such quarantine shall end and shall have the power to
order the fumigation of such premises before ending such quarantine.
(‘82 Code, § 8.12.020)
§ 91.37 UNLAWFUL SPREAD OF CONTAGIOUS OR EPIDEMIC DISEASE.
   It is unlawful for any person to wilfully or carelessly spread any
contagious or epidemic disease, or to cause or allow the spread of the same.
(‘82 Code, § 8.12.030)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 91.38 DELIVERY OR PICKUP OF FOOD OR FOOD CONTAINERS FROM QUARANTINE PREMISES.
   (A)   No person engaged in the delivery of food or drink intended for human
consumption shall enter any premises which are quarantined because of the
existence of a contagious or infectious disease.
   (B)   No containers or bottles shall be removed from any such premises until
the termination of the quarantine, and no container which has been left at the
premises during the time of the quarantine shall be used for carrying food or
drink intended for human consumption until it has been thoroughly sterilized.
(‘82 Code, § 8.12.040)
Penalty, see § 10.99
NUISANCES
§ 91.50 NUISANCES PROHIBITED.
   It is unlawful for any person to create, cause or permit a nuisance, as
defined in §
91.57, to exist or be maintained within the limits of the city.
(Ord. 976, passed 7-6-93)
Penalty, see § 91.99
§ 91.51 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   HIGHWAY. Any street, alley or public way within the city.
   INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE. Any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at
least seven days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or on
which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise
so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor
power. INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE shall also include those motor vehicles not
currently licensed, or motor vehicles currently licensed but not displaying the
license, by this state or any other state or county exposed to the view of the
general public.  INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE shall not include:
      (1)   A motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of
being driven under its own motor power in order to perform ordinary service or
repair operations.
      (2)   Any motor vehicle that is kept within a building when not in use.
      (3)   Operable historical vehicles over 25 years of age which are
currently licensed, and displaying said license, by this state or any other
state or county.
      (4)   A motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in
the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles and so licensed as a place of
business under the ordinances of the city.
   NUISANCE. Whatever is injurious to health, indecent or offensive to the
senses or an obstacle to the free use of property so as essentially to
interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property. The following are
declared to be nuisances; provided, however, that the following shall not be
deemed to be exclusive:
      (1)   The unnecessary or unauthorized erecting, continuing or using any
building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or
manufacture, which by occasioning noxious exhalation, offensive smells or other
annoyances becomes injurious and dangerous to the health, comfort or property
of individuals or the public;
      (2)   The obstructing or impeding without legal authority the passage of
any navigable river, harbor or collection of water;
      (3)   The corrupting or rendering unwholesome or impure the water of any
river, stream or pond, or unlawfully diverting the same from its natural course
or state to the injury or prejudice of others;
      (4)   The obstructing or encumbering by fences, buildings or otherwise
the public roads, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, landing places or
burying grounds;
      (5)   Billboards, signboards and advertising signs, whether erected and
constructed on public or private property, which so obstruct and impair the
view of any portion or part of a public street, avenue, highway, boulevard or
alley or of a railroad or street railway track as to render dangerous the use
thereof;
      (6)   All unnecessary or unauthorized substances which emit or cause
foul, obnoxious, unhealthful, putrid, noisome or disagreeable odor or effluvia
and which are objectionable or offensive to any person or persons residing near
the same or to any person passing along any street, sidewalk or alley near the
same;
      (7)   For any person to dump, deposit, store or place any garbage,
rubbish, trash or refuse upon property within the city, except as may be
allowed by city ordinance or state and federal regulations;
      (8)   To cause or permit any premises within the city to become or remain
littered with tin cans, glass jars, bottles, scrap glass, paper cartons, scraps
of paper, boxes, ashes, iron, old hot water tanks, oil storage tanks, tin or
other metal materials, refuse, rubbish, junk, waste, manure, straw, piles of
grass clippings, lumber, old bricks, concrete blocks, chunks of broken
concrete, plaster board, discarded furniture, household appliances, mattresses,
bedsprings, portable swimming pools in disrepair, tires or other like matters
of things;
      (9)   To create or permit to be created or remain upon any premises
within the city for a period of more than 30 days the storing, piling,
scattering, accumulating, heaping, amassing or collecting bricks, concrete
materials, straw, lumber, structural iron, pipe, roofing materials or any
building materials where the same is in public view and where the same may or
does constitute a safety hazard to children playing in the area or so that the
same may or does become an attraction to or haven for vermin or rodents;
building materials stored outdoors on any site for construction authorized by a
building permit shall not be permitted to remain more than 30 days after
completion of construction upon a job site;
      (10)   To cause or permit the existence or storage in any place
accessible to children of any abandoned or discarded refrigerator, icebox, ice
chest, deep freeze or other airtight appliance or container of any kind of a
capacity of one and one-half cubic feet or more from which the lids, doors or
other covers have not been removed, or which cannot easily be opened by a
child, by means of pushing only, from the inside;
      (11)   Permitting or causing the carcasses of animals to remain exposed
more than 12 hours after death;
      (12)   All slop, foul or dirty water, filth or refuse or offal discharged
in or upon any street, avenue, sidewalk, alley, park, public square or public
or private enclosure or allowed to accumulate there or in a pond or pool;
      (13)   To obstruct any water source, ravine or gutter so as to cause
water to stagnate therein, or permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon any
premises;
      (14)    To allow an unkept appearance to exist on the parkway immediately
adjacent to private property as caused by rubbish, debris or overgrown,
uncultivated plant life;
      (15)   Nuisance as stated in sections of the city code;
      (16)   Any abandoned or partially dismantled, derelict, nonoperating,
wrecked or junked vehicle; a vehicle in a state of substantial disrepair on any
street, highway or public place within the city; any such vehicle in public
view on any private property for more that seven days; any motor vehicle parked
in the front yard of a residential or commercial property in the city for more
than 24 hours; or more than five motor vehicles parked in public view on
private property for a period of more than 24 hours;
      (17)   Any inoperable motor vehicle which is located for seven days or
more upon public or private property in the city which is in public view. Each
motor vehicle which is permitted to exist as a nuisance shall be considered a
separate nuisance and, therefore, also constitutes the basis for a separate
offense.
   OPERABLE HISTORICAL VEHICLE. Any motor vehicle or other vehicle in an
operable condition which is 25 years of age or older and is currently licensed,
and displaying said license, by this state or any other state or county.
   PROPERTY OWNER. The contract purchaser if there is one of record, otherwise
the record holder of legal title.
   PUBLIC VIEW. Visible from the adjoining property, street or avenue.
   RUBBISH. Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and
noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin
cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials.
(Ord. 976, passed 7-6-93; Am. Ord. 1057, passed 10-1-96)
§ 91.52 NOTICE OF VIOLATION.
   The Chief of Police, or his or her designee, shall cause notice to be given
to the personal property owner of each violation of this subchapter upon
receiving a signed complaint. Such notice shall be in writing, define the
violation and describe the location of the violation. The notice shall be
served personally or forwarded by United States mail to the last known address
of the person or property owner. Further, the notice shall demand abatement of
the nuisance within ten days from the date the notice was served or mailed. If
the nuisance is not remedied within such period of time, the city may cause
such nuisance to be remedied at the exclusive cost of the person violating this
subchapter. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, the Chief of Police or
his or her designee may charge the owner of any motor vehicle causing a
nuisance as described in §
91.51(15) of this subchapter as any other traffic violation under this code and
no notice is required as herein described, and the penalty for such violation
shall be the penalty as described under the general penalty provisions of the
code as it applies to other traffic violations under this code.
(Ord. 976, passed 7-6-93)
§ 91.53 LIEN.
   In the event that payment of the actual costs of the abatement of any
nuisance by the city under the provisions of this subchapter is not made on
demand, such costs shall become a lien upon the property from which such
nuisance was abated.
(Ord. 976, passed 7-6-93)
§ 91.54 VIOLATIONS.
   Every person who creates, causes or permits a nuisance under this subchapter
and every owner, occupant, agent or trustee of any premises where such nuisance
exists who fails or refuses to abate the same as provided in this subchapter
shall be deemed guilty of violating this subchapter; and each day that such
nuisance continues after the date of abatement as set forth in the notice
required herein shall constitute and be a separate and distinct violation
thereof.
(Ord. 976, passed 7-6-93)
Penalty, see § 91.99
§ 91.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter
for which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon conviction,
be subject to a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $750 for each offense.
A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day during which a
violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 976, passed 7-6-93; Am. Ord. 1368, passed 4-7-08; Am. Ord. 1713, passed -
-)
