GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 92.001 DISPLAY OF GOODS OR ADVERTISEMENTS ON PUBLIC WAY UNLAWFUL.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to use any street,
sidewalk or other public place for the display of goods or merchandise for sale
or to write or mark any signs or advertisements upon any such place.
(‘82 Code, § 12.44.010)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.002 ENCROACHING STRUCTURE.
   It is unlawful to erect or maintain any building or other structure which
encroaches upon any public street or property.
(‘82 Code, § 12.44.020)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.003 UNLAWFUL DEPOSITS; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   It is unlawful to deposit on any street or sidewalk anything which
might be harmful to the pavement thereof or any glass, refuse or waste
material, or any other article which might do injury to any person, animal or
property.
   (B)   Coal, building materials or other like material may be deposited in
the street preparatory to delivery or use, provided that such deposit does not
reduce the usable width of the street or roadway at any point to less than 18
feet; and provided, that such coal or material, other than material to be used
in actual building construction, shall not be permitted to remain on the street
for more than three hours. Any such material or coal shall be properly guarded
by lights if it remains on the streets after nighttime.
(‘82 Code, § 12.44.030)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.004 OBSTRUCTION OF DRAIN.
   It is unlawful to obstruct any drain in any public street or alley.
(‘82 Code, § 12.44.040)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.005 ERECTION OF POLES AND WIRES.
   It is unlawful to erect or maintain any poles or wires over any public
street or alley without having first obtained permission from the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 12.44.050)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.006 ERECTION OF GAS PUMP OR TANK; BOND.
   It is unlawful hereafter to erect any gas pump or tank in any public street
or alley without having first obtained permission from the Council. No such
permit shall be issued until the applicant furnishes a bond with corporate
surety, conditioned to indemnify the city against any loss or liability
occasioned by such pump or tank, in the sum of $5,000.
(‘82 Code, § 12.44.060)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.007 PLAYING GAMES IN STREET.
   It is unlawful to play any game upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other
public way where such games may interfere with vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
(‘82 Code, § 12.44.070)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.008 MAINTAINING OPENING IN STREET.
   It is unlawful to maintain or construct any opening or stairway in any
public street, alley or sidewalk without a permit of the Council. All such
lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitable railing or cover.
(‘82 Code, § 12.44.080)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.009 ELECTRIC FENCE UNLAWFUL.
   It is unlawful to construct or maintain any fence composed in whole or in
part of barbed wire or any wire charged with electric current anywhere within
three feet of any public street or alley, sidewalk, park or other public way or
place.
(‘82 Code, § 12.44.090)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.010 TURNOFF OF PARK LIGHTS.
   All lights in all public parks shall be turned off at the hour of 10:30
p.m., except those lights deemed necessary for public safety by the City Police
Committee.
(‘82 Code, § 12.44.100) (Ord. 687, passed - -75)
§ 92.011 ROAD GRAVELING FEE.
   (A)   It is determined to be in the best interests of the city and its
inhabitants that when new roads are requested in a new subdivision or elsewhere
which are to be covered with gravel that the owners of the property on either
side of such road shall pay for the gravel at an amount to be determined from
time to time by the city.
(‘82 Code, § 12.08.010)
   (B)   The city will not be required to gravel such road unless the owners on
both sides of the road owning real estate shall pay an amount to be determined
from time to time by the city per running foot for the total frontage, or
unless the owner of real estate on one side of the road shall pay for both
sides of the total frontage at an amount to be determined from time to time by
the city.
(‘82 Code, § 12.08.020)
(Ord. 566, passed - -64; Ord. 616, passed - -67; Ord. 728, passed - -78)
§ 92.012 OBSTRUCTING ACCESS TO PUBLIC BUILDINGS, STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND THE
LIKE.
   (A)   No person shall obstruct any street, park, public place or any public
building, obstruct the access to any public building, or any part thereof, or
obstruct passage through or upon any public street, park or public place.
   (B)   For the purpose of this section, the term "obstruct" encompasses, but
is not necessarily limited to one or more of the following acts:
      (1)   Obstruction of the free, unhampered passage of pedestrians or
vehicles;
      (2)   Obstructing, molesting or interfering with any person lawfully upon
any street, park or other public place;
      (3)   Obstructing or otherwise interfering with the free passage of
persons entering or occupying such buildings or premises;
      (4)   Use of language, conversation or conduct which annoys, insults or
disturbs persons passing along the street or other public places or occupying,
residing or doing business in any of such houses or places;
      (5)   Refusing to move on when so requested by a peace officer, provided
that the peace officer has exercised his or her discretion reasonably under the
circumstances in order to preserve or promote public peace and order.
(‘82 Code, § 12.48.010) (Ord. 749, passed - -80)
Penalty, see § 92.999
CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR
§ 92.025 ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY.
   All public streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public ways in the city
shall be under the supervision of the Superintendent of Streets. He or she
shall be charged with the enforcement of all ordinance provisions relating to
such public places and is authorized to enforce such ordinances.
(‘82 Code, § 12.04.010)
§ 92.026 CONSTRUCTION PERMIT; APPLICATION, BOND.
   (A)   Application procedure. It is unlawful to construct or lay any pavement
on any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public way without having first
secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the
City Clerk and shall state the location of the intended pavement or repair, the
extent thereof and the person or firm who is to do the actual work. No such
permit shall be issued except on order of the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 12.04.020)
   (B)   Bond requirement. Each applicant shall file a bond in the amount to be
approved by the Council with such surety as may be approved by the Council,
conditioned to indemnify the city for any loss or damage resulting from the
work or the manner of doing the same.
(‘82 Code, § 12.04.030)
§ 92.027 CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS.
   All street and sidewalk pavements shall be made in conformity with
specifications laid down or approved from time to time by the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 12.04.040)
§ 92.028 INJURING NEWLY LAID PAVEMENT.
   It is unlawful to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon or injure
any newly laid pavement while the same is guarded by a warning sign or
barricade, or to knowingly injure any newly laid pavement.
(‘82 Code, § 12.04.050)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.029 UNLAWFUL OBSTRUCTION OF STREET OR SIDEWALK.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to cause, create or
maintain any obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way
except as may be specifically authorized by ordinance or by the Superintendent
of Streets.
(‘82 Code, § 12.04.060)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.030 BARRICADE; REQUIREMENT, INTERFERENCE.
   (A)   Requirement.
      (1)   Any person, firm or corporation laying or repairing any pavement on
any street, sidewalk or other public place or making any excavation in any such
place shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or
vehicle. Such barricades shall be protected by lights at night.
      (2)   Any defects in any pavement shall be barricaded to prevent injury,
and any person, firm or corporation properly maintaining any excavation or
opening in any such place shall guard such opening by proper barricades and
lights.
(‘82 Code, § 12.04.070)
   (B)   Interference unlawful. It is unlawful to disturb or interfere with any
light or barricade properly placed to prevent injury or to protect or mark any
pavement or excavation in any street, alley or sidewalk.
(‘82 Code, § 12.04.080) Penalty, see §
92.999
§ 92.031 MANDATORY SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION.
   It is determined by the City Council that it is in the best interest of the
public welfare of the residents of the city that sidewalks be constructed at
the time of construction of any new residence or commercial building. From the
effective date of this section, a sidewalk shall be installed at the time of
construction of any new residential, commercial or industrial structure. No
building permit for construction of a dwelling or commercial or industrial
structure shall be issued for any lot or parcel in the city until such time as
the applicant has provided plans approved by the Public Works Director to
insure that a sidewalk is constructed on the lot or parcel in full compliance
with all regulations of the city and in full compliance with any requirements
of the Public Works Director, at the sole cost of the applicant or owner of the
real estate. The City Council shall have the authority to waive this
requirement by majority vote.
(Ord. 1454, passed 6-4-12) Penalty, see §
92.999
EXCAVATION REGULATIONS
§ 92.045 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to tunnel under or
make any excavation in any street, alley or other public place in the city
without having obtained a permit as required in this subchapter or without
complying with the provisions of this subchapter or in violation of or variance
from the terms of any such permit.
   (B)   The provisions of this subchapter related to securing permits shall
not apply to officers or employees of the city engaged in doing work for the
city, nor to persons or corporations doing work for the city under contract,
nor to persons or corporations which are operating under a franchise or grant
from the city if such franchise provides for the making of excavations and
tunnels without securing a permit therefor.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.010) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.046 PERMIT APPLICATION AND ISSUANCE.
   (A)   Applications for such permits shall be made to the Clerk and shall
describe the location of the intended excavation or tunnel, the size thereof,
the purpose therefor and the person, firm or corporation for whom or which the
work is being done and shall contain an agreement that the applicant will
comply with all ordinances and laws relating to the work to be done.
   (B)   No such permit shall be issued except on order of the Chairman of the
Street Committee.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.020) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
§ 92.047 PERMIT FEE.
   The fee for such permits shall be an amount to be determined from time to
time by the city.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.030) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
§ 92.048 PERMIT DEPOSIT.
   No such permit shall be issued unless and until the applicant therefor has
deposited with the City Clerk a cash deposit in an amount to be determined from
time to time by the city where the street surface involved is oiled or
unimproved and where the street surface involved is otherwise improved to
insure the proper restoration of the ground and laying of the pavement or other
improved surface, if any. From this deposit shall be deducted the expense to
the city of relaying the surface by the city if at its expense, and the balance
shall be returned to the applicant without interest after the tunnel or
excavation is completely refilled and the surface or pavement is restored.
These deposits shall be made whether the work to be done is done by city
employees or otherwise.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.040) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
§ 92.049 BARRICADING REQUIRED.
   Any person, firm or corporation making or maintaining any excavation in any
street or alley shall keep the same adequately guarded by barricades and lights
to protect persons and property from injury.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.050) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.050 EXCAVATION METHODS.
   (A)   It is unlawful to make any excavation or tunnel in any way contrary to
or at variance with the terms of the permit therefor. Proper bracing shall be
maintained to prevent the collapse of adjoining grounds, and in excavations,
the excavation shall not have anywhere below the surface any portion which
extends beyond the opening at the surface.
   (B)   No injury shall be done to any pipes, cables or conduits in the making
of such excavation or tunnel; and notice shall be given to the persons
maintaining any such pipes, cables or conduits or to the city department or
officer charged with the care thereof, which are or may be endangered or
affected by the making of any such excavation or tunnel before such pipes,
cables or conduits shall be disturbed.
   (C)   No unnecessary damage or injury shall be done to any tree, shrub or
roots thereof.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.060) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.051 TEMPORARY SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION.
   If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work, a temporary sidewalk shall be
constructed or provided which is safe for travel and convenient for users.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.070) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
§ 92.052 TIME LIMIT FOR COMPLETION OF EXCAVATION.
   Such application for a permit shall state the length of time it is estimated
will elapse from the commencement of the work until the restoration of the
surface of the ground or until the refill is made ready for the pavement to be
put on by the city if the city restores such pavement. It is unlawful to fail
to comply with this time limitation unless permission for an extension of time
is granted by the City Council.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.080) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.053 RESTORATION OF SURFACE.
   (A)   Any person, firm or corporation making any excavation or tunnel in or
under any public street, alley or public place in the city shall restore the
surface thereof to its original condition if there is no pavement there.
Refills shall be properly tamped down, and any bracing in such tunnel or
excavation shall be left in the ground.
   (B)   If the excavation or opening has necessitated an opening in a
pavement, the refill shall be properly made so that the surface pavement can be
relaid by the city in the same manner, thickness and character as the
surrounding pavement. Notice shall be given to the City Clerk when such opening
is prepared for pavement, and the pavement shall be laid by the city, either by
contract or by city employees. In either event, the surface relaid may extend
for at least one foot in every direction beyond the original opening.
   (C)   An accurate account of the expense and cost of relaying such pavement
shall be kept, and this amount shall be deducted from the cash deposit
mentioned in §
92.048 before the balance is returned.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.090) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 92.054 SUPERVISORY AUTHORITY.
   The Superintendent of Streets shall from time to time inspect all
excavations and tunnels being made in or under any public street, alley or
other public place in the city to see to the enforcement of the provisions of
this subchapter. Notice shall be given to him or her at least ten hours before
the work of refilling any such excavation or tunnel commences.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.100) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
§ 92.055 REMOVAL OF RUBBLE REQUIRED; BACKFILLING MATERIALS.
   (A)   All dirt and rubble obtained in excavating in any street or alley
shall be removed from the site.
   (B)   Sand only shall be used in backfilling any excavation in any street or
alley or other public thoroughfare.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.110) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 92.056 UNNECESSARY OBSTRUCTION BY MATERIALS PROHIBITED.
   No contractor, builder or other person shall encumber or obstruct any
street, avenue, alley or sidewalk within the city with any building material
without the consent of the Superintendent of Streets; nor, in any case, and
then for a short time only, encumber or obstruct more than one-third of the
driveway portion of any street, avenue or alley or one-half of any sidewalk;
nor shall such obstructions continue in any case longer than may be necessary
in the diligent erection of such building or the prompt execution of the work.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.120) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.057 OBSTRUCTION OF STREETS.
   (A)   Penalty. Whoever places, throws, leaves or causes to be placed, thrown
or left any obstructions or encumbrance in or upon any street, avenue or alley
within the city, except as authorized by ordinance, shall be subject to the
penalty as provided in §
92.999.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.130)
   (B)   Removal authority. Whenever any street, avenue or alley is obstructed
by vehicles, animals or persons, any member of the Police Department may give
such orders and directions as shall be deemed necessary to abate the
obstruction; and whoever shall neglect or refuse to obey such orders shall be
subject to a penalty as provided in §
92.999.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.140)
   (C)   Removal by city; method. 
      (1)   If the owner of any building, fence or other structure which
extends into or encroaches upon any street, avenue, alley or sidewalk within
the city does not remove the same promptly, he or she shall be subject to a
penalty as provided in §
92.999.
      (2)   The City Council may direct the Chief of Police or Superintendent
of Streets to take down and remove such obstruction or encroachment upon any
street, avenue, alley or sidewalk, and the cost and expense of such taking down
and removal may be collected by suit in the name of the corporation against the
person or persons maintaining, causing or erecting such encroachment or
obstruction.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.150)
(Ord. 751, passed - -80)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.058 REMOVAL OF MATERIALS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall dig, remove or carry away any earth, sand, gravel, stone,
sod, turf or other material from any street, avenue, alley or public place
within the city.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.160) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.059 VIOLATIONS.
   Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this subchapter
shall be subject to penalty as provided in §
92.999.
(‘82 Code, § 12.06.170) (Ord. 751, passed - -80)
SIDEWALK REPAIR
§ 92.075 DECLARATION OF NECESSITY.
   It is determined by the City Council that it is in the best interests of the
public welfare of the residents of the city that damaged sidewalks or sidewalks
that have fallen into disrepair be repaired, and that the repair of the
sidewalks shall be regulated by this subchapter.
(‘82 Code, § 12.12.010) (Ord. 731, passed - -78; Am. Ord. 894, passed 12-6-88;
Am. Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
§ 92.076 REMOVAL OF DAMAGED SIDEWALKS.
   Sidewalks which have fallen into disrepair or have been damaged may be
removed and replaced by the Public Works Department.
(‘82 Code, § 12.12.020) (Ord. 894, passed 12-6-88; Am. Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-
03)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 92.077 REPLACEMENT SIDEWALK - SPECIFICATIONS.
   All sidewalks shall be installed, replaced or repaired according to
specifications established by the city. The minimum width in all areas shall be
four feet and the minimum thickness shall be four inches. Expansion joints
shall be mandatory every 28 feet at a minimum or 40 feet at a maximum. Re-bar
shall be a minimum of one-half inch in diameter. Material used to construct the
sidewalk shall be concrete, with a 4000 pound per square inch six bag mix
minimum.
(‘82 Code, § 12.12.030) (Ord. 894, passed 12-6-88; Am. Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-
03)
§ 92.078 REPLACEMENT SIDEWALK - MATERIAL COST TO BE BORNE BY OWNER.
   The owner of property abutting the sidewalk being repaired shall sign an
agreement and payment must be made prior to work being performed. The owner
shall pay all cost for material and labor used in the construction of the
replacement of the sidewalk. No sidewalks will be repaired without a signed
agreement with the city. The owner of the property agrees to pay a maintenance
fee for the installation of the replacement sidewalk in an amount determined
according to the schedule of fees on file and available for public inspection
in the office of the City Clerk.
(‘82 Code, § 12.12.040) (Ord. 894, passed 12-6-88; Am. Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-
03)
§ 92.079 SIDEWALKS IN DISREPAIR — PRIORITY.
   (A)   After notification and signed agreement between the owner and the
city, the sidewalk will be assigned a priority based on the severity of damage
or need of repair and the work scheduled by the PWD according to the following
order:
      (1)   High priority. Complete replacement, two inches or more in
differential.
      (2)   Medium priority. Sectional replacement, two inches or more in
differential.
      (3)   Low priority. Complete/sectional replacement, cracked or broken.
   (B)   High priority sidewalk owners will be sent a letter after which they
have one year to sign an agreement to repair the sidewalk and the repair must
be completed in two years.
(Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
§ 92.080 NEW CONSTRUCTION.
   New construction of sidewalks shall be the responsibility of the owner/
developer and comply with specifications of this subchapter.
(Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
§ 92.081 PROGRAM DATES/RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The city's sidewalk program will begin each year on or about May 1 and end
on or about October 1, weather permitting, and will be scheduled by the Public
Works Director. The city will not replace sidewalks on private property. The
city will maintain a file on homeowners who call for sidewalk replacement and
continue to prioritize on an ongoing basis.
(Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
§ 92.082 BARRIERS REQUIRED.
   All sidewalk work in progress or newly finished, or for which any excavation
has been made, shall be surrounded and efficiently protected by ample and
sufficient barriers.
(Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
§ 92.083 UNNECESSARY OBSTRUCTION BY MATERIALS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be the duty of every sidewalk builder to so place the materials and
tools and other equipment required for construction of any sidewalk in such a
manner and place to not occupy any greater portion of the streets, avenues, or
public places of the city than is absolutely necessary in properly carrying on
the work and shall take such means as may be necessary to prevent the
obstruction of any gutter in any such street or avenue.
(Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
§ 92.084 OBSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS.
   Pursuant to authority granted to the city by ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, no person
or entity shall obstruct sidewalks in the city in any manner or with any
material, including snow, dirt, sand, rock and gravel, that impedes the flow of
pedestrian traffic thereon or that creates any hazardous conditions endangering
pedestrian traffic thereon.
(Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
§ 92.085 UNNECESSARY OCCUPATION BY TOOLS AND MATERIALS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be the duty of every sidewalk builder, as soon as the builder has
completed the construction of any sidewalk, to immediately remove tools,
equipment, and all surplus material. The builder shall not deliver tools,
equipment or materials to the location of any such sidewalk for any unnecessary
or unreasonable length of time in advance of the commencement of such work.
(Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
§ 92.086 LANDSCAPING FINISHED SIDEWALKS.
   It shall be the responsibility of the person or persons replacing or
constructing the sidewalk to return the surrounding area as close as possible
to its original condition.
(Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
§ 92.087 MAINTENANCE OF SIDEWALK; OWNER RESPONSIBILITY.
   (A)   The maintenance and repair of all sidewalks, including the cost of
such maintenance and repair, shall be the sole responsibility of the owner of
the property abutting the sidewalk. The city and the state shall not be
considered abutting property owners.
   (B)   It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the abutting property
to keep the sidewalk in such a state of repair so as to ensure safe travel
thereon.
(Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
§ 92.088 ASSESSMENT OF COSTS AND REPAIRS.
   If the owner of the abutting property to the sidewalk fails, refuses or
neglects to comply with the requirements for repairs or maintenance provided in
this subchapter, the city may proceed to complete the repairs or maintenance of
the sidewalk and pursuant to ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, may require payment of the
whole or any part of the cost thereof by the abutting property owner.
(Ord. 1207, passed 4-15-03)
ENCROACHMENTS
§ 92.090 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ENCROACHMENT. Any building, fence, sign or any other structure or object of
any kind (with the exception of utilities and public road signs) which is
placed, located or maintained in, on, under or over any portion of the roadway
right-of-way.
   ROADWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY. Those areas existing or acquired by dedication or by
fee simple for highway purposes; also, the areas acquired by temporary easement
during the time the easement is in effect.
(‘82 Code, § 12.16.010) (Ord. 655, passed - -73)
§ 92.091 ENCROACHMENT PROHIBITED.
   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect or cause to be
erected, to retain or cause to be retained an encroachment within the limits of
the roadway right-of-way.
(‘82 Code, § 12.16.020) (Ord. 655, passed - -73)
Penalty, see § 92.999
DRIVEWAYS
§ 92.105 PERMIT; APPLICATION, FEE.
   No person, firm or corporation shall construct a driveway for vehicles or
animals across any sidewalk in the city without having first obtained a permit
therefor from the Council. Applications for such permits shall be made to the
City Clerk and shall be accompanied by an amount to be determined from time to
time by the city.
(‘82 Code, § 12.20.010)
§ 92.106 CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS.
   (A)   No driveway shall be so constructed or graded as to leave a step,
sharp depression or other obstruction in the sidewalk. The grade shall be as
nearly as possible the same as that of the adjoining sidewalk.
   (B)   It is unlawful to have the surface finish of any driveway, where the
same crosses the sidewalk, constructed of such materials as to render it
slippery or hazardous to pedestrians or to have the grade of the sidewalk be
other than level.
(‘82 Code, § 12.20.020)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.107 MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENT.
   It is the duty of the person, firm or corporation maintaining any such
driveway to keep the same free from snow and ice and to keep it in good repair
and free from opening and obstructions.
(‘82 Code, § 12.20.030)
Penalty, see § 92.999
SIGNS; AWNINGS
§ 92.120 PERMIT REQUIREMENT.
   No person, firm or corporation shall erect or maintain any sign, signboard
or rigid canopy over any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way without
having first obtained a permit therefor.
(‘82 Code, § 12.28.010)
§ 92.121 MINIMUM HEIGHTS.
   The lowest part of any such canopy, sign or any nonrigid awning, or any
support thereof, shall be at least seven feet above the level of the walk or
public way over which it extends, but no such sign shall be maintained over any
public way used by vehicles if any part of the sign or its support is less than
15 feet above the level of such public way.
(‘82 Code, § 12.28.020)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.122 CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS.
   All signs or canopies extending over any public street, alley, sidewalk or
other public place must be securely fastened and constructed so that there is
no danger of the same being dislodged by ordinary winds or of falling from any
cause.
(‘82 Code, § 12.28.030)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.123 POLICE CHIEF INSPECTION DUTY; ABATEMENT PROCEDURE.
   It is the duty of the Chief of Police to inspect or cause to be inspected at
regular intervals every sign, canopy or awning which extends over any public
way. If any such sign is insecure, he or she shall report this to the owner or
occupant of the premises upon which the sign is located. If the sign is not
made secure within ten days after such notice, it may be torn down on order of
the City Council.
(‘82 Code, § 12.28.040)
SUBSTREET OR SIDEWALK SPACE
§ 92.135 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   It is unlawful to construct or maintain any vault, space, room or other
structure under any street, alley or sidewalk without having first obtained a
permit therefor.
(‘82 Code, § 12.32.010)
§ 92.136 APPLICATION PROCEDURE; BOND.
   Applications for such permits shall be made to the City Clerk and shall be
accompanied by an amount to be determined from time to time by the city and by
a bond or indemnity policy, with corporate surety in the sum of $10,000
conditioned to indemnify the city for any loss or damage or liability that may
result from the construction or maintenance of such vault, room or structure.
Each application shall show thereon the size of such structure and the purpose
for which it is intended to be used.
(‘82 Code, § 12.32.020)
§ 92.137 CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS; MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENT.
   Such vaults, spaces, rooms or structures shall be so constructed as to
support the sidewalk or street over them with a maximum load which the street
or sidewalk will carry, plus a margin of safety of 50%, and the person
maintaining such a structure shall keep the street or sidewalk over such
structure in good repair.
(‘82 Code, § 12.32.030)
WEIGHT LIMITS
§ 92.150 CONDITIONS.
   During any time of the year when the streets are in danger of damage by use
of vehicles operating with the weight limits described in section § 92.151,
whether by reason of deterioration of the streets, rain, snow, frost leaving
the ground or other conditions, the city may restrict the use of vehicles and
may reduce the permissible weight limits or load limits upon any streets of the
city.
(Ord. 989A, passed 2-1-94)
Cross reference:
   Weight limits, see
Ch. 71, Sch. V
§ 92.151 PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   The Mayor, notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary in this
subchapter, may issue a written special permit, at his or her sole discretion,
to anyone upon application and a showing of good cause and taking into
consideration the condition of the particular streets requested, authorizing
the applicant to use certain city streets or a portion thereof, temporarily,
for a specific trip or series of trips. In addition, the Mayor may require such
security as he or she deems necessary to compensate for injury to the streets
prior to granting such temporary permit.
(Ord. 989A, passed 2-1-94)
§ 92.152 VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   The Mayor may declare, at any time when conditions as described in §
92.150 are present, in his or her sole discretion, that the load limit or
permissible weight limit on any streets shall be reduced to the following gross
weight:
   Two axles, single rear tires:            7,000 pounds
   Two axles, dual rear tires:            18,000 pounds
   Three (3) or more axles, dual rear/trailer      33,000 pounds
   For all vehicles, the maximum axle load per axles shall not exceed 11,000
pounds.
   (B)   The above restrictions shall apply immediately upon the declaration by
the Mayor of which streets or areas of streets shall be subject to the above
weight limits and at such time as signs have been erected designating the
provisions of this section at each end of the affected portion of each street.
The above restriction shall apply for a total period of not to exceed 120 days
in any one calendar year.
(Ord. 989A, passed 2-1-94)
Penalty, see § 92.999
VACATION OF STREETS AND ALLEYS
§ 92.160 VACATION OF STREETS AND ALLEYS.
   The following rules and regulations shall be established and shall be
followed by the City Council in determining whether or not to vacate any street
or alley in the city:
   (A)   If the Council determines that the public interest of the city will be
served thereby, the Council may adopt an ordinance to vacate a street or alley
or a part thereof, upon an affirmative vote of three-fourths of the aldermen
then holding office, during a regular or special Council meeting.
   (B)   All ordinances, resolutions, and motions of the Council relating to
this section shall comply with all laws of the state governing the vacation of
streets and alleys by a municipality.
   (C)   Any request for vacation of a street or alley by any person or entity
other than the city shall follow the procedure set forth below:
      (1)   The applicant shall make a verbal request to the City
Administrator. The City Council shall review the request and shall vote to
either recommend or deny the request (“preliminary vote”). No Alderman shall be
bound to vote for or against an ordinance granting a vacation based upon the
preliminary vote.
      (2)   After the preliminary vote, the applicant may file a written
petition requesting the vacation of a street or alley which petition shall
include the following:
         (a)   A filing fee in the amount of $60.
         (b)   A complete description and accurate map of the area to be
vacated.
         (c)   The reason for the request.
         (d)   A statement listing all public utilities located in the proposed
area to be vacated.
      (3)   If the City Council denies the application, the filing fee shall be
refunded if the majority of the Council had voted in favor of the vacation at
the preliminary vote.
      (4)   The City Council shall determine the estimated fair market value of
the street or alley requested to be vacated at its sole cost and expense.
   (D)   The petitioner shall be required to contact JULIE or its successor or
equivalent to locate all underground public utilities in the proposed area to
be vacated.
   (E)   The Council shall determine by majority vote whether or not a notice
of the vacation of the street or alley shall be published at least once in the
Fulton Journal not less than 15 days before the meeting to be held to pass the
ordinance to vacate the street or alley. No publication notice shall be
required unless required by state law or required by Council action.
   (F)   No vacation ordinance shall become effective until the owners of all
property or the owners of a particular parcel or parcels of property abutting
upon the street or alley, or part thereof so vacated, shall pay compensation in
an amount which, in the judgment of the Council, shall be the fair market value
of the property acquired or of the benefits which will accrue to them by reason
of that vacation.
   (G)   If any public service facilities located in, under, over, or upon such
street or alley, or any part thereof, or in the judgment of the city public
service facilities may be installed anytime in the future, the ordinance may
reserve to the city or to any public utility, as the case may be, owning such
facilities, such licenses, rights-of-way or easements as, in the judgment of
the city, are necessary or desirable for continuing public service by means of
those facilities now or in the future and for the maintenance, renewal and
reconstruction thereof.
   (H)   The Council shall have the authority to determine which adjoining
property owner or owners shall be permitted to obtain ownership of the area to
be vacated and what part of the area to be vacated each owner or owners shall
receive, as permitted by the Illinois Municipal Code. If the ordinance provides
that only the owner or owners of one particular parcel of abutting property
shall make payment, then the owner or owners of the particular parcel shall
acquire title to the entire vacated street or alley, or the part thereof
vacated.
   (I)   The determination by the Council that the nature and extent of the
public use or public interest to be served is such as to warrant the vacation
of any street or alley, or part thereof, is conclusive, and the passage of such
an ordinance is sufficient evidence of that determination, whether recited in
the ordinance or not. The relief to the public from further burden and
responsibility of maintaining any street or alley, or part thereof, constitutes
a public use or public interest authorizing a vacation.
(Ord. 1282, passed 6-6-05; Am. Ord. 1459, passed 7-2-12)
PUBLIC GATHERINGS
§ 92.165 BUILDING CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENT.
   It is unlawful to hold, manage or conduct any meeting or entertainment of
any kind in the city in any premises other than a building constructed in full
compliance with the ordinances and laws pertaining thereto for auditorium,
theater or lodge room purposes, excepting in compliance with the provisions of
this subchapter.
(‘82 Code, § 8.36.010)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.166 PREMISES INSPECTION REQUIREMENT.
   No such gathering or entertainment shall be held or presented in any
premises other than a building as described in §
92.165, unless such premises shall have been examined by a Fire Marshal or the
Chief of the Fire Department before the date of such gathering and found to be
free of any fire hazard and to be suitable for the purpose.
(‘82 Code, § 8.36.020)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.167 CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Roof.  No structure enclosed by a roof shall be used for such purpose
unless the same is constructed of nonflammable materials; provided, tents or
similar structures may be used if such canvass or other material has been
properly treated so as to render it fire-resistive.
(‘82 Code, § 8.36.030)
   (B)   Exits.  
      (1)   Adequate unobstructed exits shall be provided in all premises used
for such purposes to permit rapid egress of all persons attending, and there
shall be at least two separate exits located at least 30 feet from each other.
      (2)   There shall be at least two lineal feet of doorway or exit space
for each 100 people accommodated.
      (3)   All doors or gates shall open outward and no such exit shall be so
constructed or locked that egress from the inside of the premises is blocked.
(‘82 Code, § 8.36.040)
   (C)   Stands and row of seats. Any stands or rows of seats used in such
premises shall be so constructed as to be safe for the use designated and shall
be sufficiently strong to carry the same weight or stress as is required for
the construction of auditorium floors of theater buildings.
(‘82 Code, § 8.36.050)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.168 ADMISSIONS IN EXCESS OF SEATING PROHIBITED.
   It is unlawful to admit to such premises a number of people to exceed the
number of actual seats maintained for their accommodation.
(‘82 Code, § 8.36.060)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.169 ADVANCE NOTICE TO CITY; COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENT.
   It shall be the duty of any person conducting any meeting or gathering in
any premises other than a theater, lodge room or auditorium, constructed as
provided in §
92.165, to notify the City Clerk at least ten days in advance of such meeting,
stating the location and intended use of the premises; upon such notice, the
Fire Marshal, or such person as he or she shall designate, shall inspect the
premises to determine whether or not they comply with the provisions hereof.
Any permit for any such gathering shall be issued subject to the condition that
this subchapter be fully complied with, whether or not such condition is
embodied in such permit.
(‘82 Code, § 8.36.070)
Penalty, see § 92.999
§ 92.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this
code for which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon
conviction, be subject to a fine not less than $100 and not less than $750. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during which a
violation occurs or continues.
   (B)   The penalty for the violation of §
92.012 shall be no less than $50 plus costs for the first offense and no more
than $200 for the first offense; the minimum fine shall be $150 plus court
costs, the maximum fine being $750 plus court costs. (‘82 Code, § 12.48.020)
   (C)   Any person violating any of the provisions or failing to comply with
any of the mandatory requirements of §§
93.045 et seq. shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Except in cases where a
different punishment is prescribed by any ordinance of the city, any person
convicted of a misdemeanor under the ordinances of the city shall be punished
by a fine of not more than $750, or by imprisonment not to exceed six months,
or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each person shall be guilty of a
separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any
violation of any provision of the ordinances of the city is committed,
continued or permitted by any such person, and he or she shall be punished
accordingly. (‘82 Code, § 12.06.180)
   (D)   (1)   Any person violating any provision of §§
92.150 et seq. shall be fined an amount equal to the following schedule:
         Up to and including 5,000 pounds overweight:      $500
         From 5,001 through 7,000 pounds overweight:      $600
         From 7,001 or more pounds overweight:         $750
      (2)   Bail for any violation of these sections shall be set out in an
amount equal to the amount of the fine fixed by this division of this section.
(Ord. 749, passed - -80; Ord. 751, passed - -80; Ord. 989A, passed 2-1-94; Am.
Ord. 1713, passed - -)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 93.01 PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   (A)   It is unlawful to plant or set, to cut down, remove or disturb any
tree or bush in any public street, parkway or other public place without having
first secured a permit therefor.
   (B)   Applications for such permits shall be made to the City Clerk and
shall be referred to and approved by the Council before issuance.
   (C)   All such planting shall be placed subject to the approval of the
Superintendent of Streets.
(‘82 Code, § 12.24.010)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 93.02 ATTACHING SIGN OR INJURING TREE OR SHRUB.
   It is unlawful to attach any sign, notice or advertisement to or to
otherwise injure any tree or shrub in any public place.
(‘82 Code, § 12.24.020)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 93.03 TREE OR SHRUB IMPEDING PUBLIC WAY; TRIMMING REQUIREMENT.
   Any tree or shrub which overhangs any street, sidewalk or other public place
in the city in such a way as to impede or interfere with traffic or travel
shall be trimmed by the owner of the premises abutting or of the premises on
which such tree or shrub grows so that the obstruction shall cease.
(‘82 Code, § 12.24.030)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 93.04 TREE OR LIMB LIKELY TO FALL ON PUBLIC WAY; REMOVAL REQUIREMENT.
   (A)   Any tree or limb of a tree which has became likely to fall on or
across any street, sidewalk or other public place shall be removed by the owner
of the premises on which such tree grows or stands.
   (B)   If such person does not proceed to abate such nuisance within ten
days, the City Administrator shall proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an
account of the expenses of such abatement, and such expense shall be charged to
and paid by such owner or occupant.
(‘82 Code, § 12.24.040)
§ 93.05 KEEPING POLES AND WIRES FREE AND AWAY FROM TREES OR SHRUBS.
   Any person, firm or corporation which maintains poles or wires in the
streets, alleys or other public places shall, in the absence of provisions in
the franchise concerning the subject, keep such poles and wires free from and
away from any trees or shrubs in any such public places as far as may be
possible, and shall keep all such trees and shrubs near such poles or wires
properly trimmed so that no injury shall be done either to the trees or shrubs
or to the poles or wires by their contact.
(‘82 Code, § 12.24.050)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 93.06 ATTACHING ROPE OR WIRES TO TREES OR SHRUBS PROHIBITED.
   It is unlawful to attach any wire or rope to any tree or shrub in any public
street, parkway or other public place without permission of the Council.
(‘82 Code, § 12.24.060)
Penalty, see § 10.99

DUTCH ELM DISEASE
§ 93.20 CITY OFFICER INSPECTION RIGHT.
   The officers, agents, servants and employees of the city are authorized and
directed to enter on and upon private property whereon there is located any elm
tree having the appearance of or suspected of being diseased with Phloem
necrosis, commonly called the dutch elm disease, for the purpose of inspecting
the suspected tree and removing therefrom samples or portions thereof to be
tested to establish whether the tree is in fact diseased.
(‘82 Code, § 8.32.010) (Ord. 538, passed - -61)
§ 93.21 DISEASED TREE DECLARED NUISANCE.
   In the event that it is determined that the tree from which the samples have
been taken is in fact diseased or infected with the dutch elm tree disease,
said tree shall be declared to be a nuisance.
(‘82 Code, § 8.32.020) (Ord. 538, passed - -61)
§ 93.22 OWNER ABATEMENT REQUIREMENT.
   The owner, occupant or agent of the parcel of land on which the diseased elm
tree exists shall remove and destroy the elm tree and shall burn the same or
shall cause the same to be removed, destroyed and burned within ten days of
notification to such owner, occupant or agent that the elm tree is in fact
diseased and infected.
(‘82 Code, § 8.32.030) (Ord. 538, passed - -61)
§ 93.23 CITY ABATEMENT.
   In all cases where the owner, occupant or agent of the parcel of land on
which the diseased elm tree is located cannot be found, or if found and
notified as aforesaid neglects or refuses to abate the same by the removal,
destruction and burning of said diseased elm tree, and in that event the owner,
occupant and agent or any of them shall be charged with those expenses which
may be incurred by the city in the removal or abatement of the diseased elm
tree as aforesaid, the expense shall be collected by the city by suit or
otherwise in addition to the fine or penalty provided in this code.
(‘82 Code, § 8.32.040) (Ord. 538, passed - -61)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 93.24 UNLAWFUL POSSESSION OF DISEASED TREE ON PREMISES IN CITY.
   It is unlawful for the owner of any premises in the city to permit any tree
or portion thereof infected with the dutch elm disease to remain on such
premises.
(‘82 Code, § 8.32.050) (Ord. 538, passed - -61)
Penalty, see § 10.99

GENERAL REGULATIONS
§ 94.01 KEEPING OR MAINTENANCE OF ANIMALS.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to keep or maintain within the city
limits any animal of the species of horse, mule, sheep, goat, swine or poultry
without written permission of the City Council. Any operating farm shall be
allowed to maintain livestock if the farm exists on the date of this section.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person to keep or allow to be kept on the
premises owned, occupied or lawfully controlled by such person within the city
more than four dogs or four cats or four other domesticated animals or any
combination of dog, cats, or animals of the age of six months or older.
Domesticated animals shall not include birds or fish.
   (C)   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, it shall be lawful to keep a
newborn litter totaling more than four dogs or four cats or four other
domesticated animals for a period of six months from date of birth of such
litter. Six months from the date the litter is delivered, the person shall
comply with the limitations described in this section.
   (D)   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, it shall be lawful to keep
or maintain more than four dogs or four cats or four other domesticated animals
or any combination of dogs, cats, or animals, if such person is a licensed
kennel or animal hospital validly located in the city pursuant to city
ordinances or the person has obtained written permission from the City Council.
(‘82 Code, § 6.04.010) (Ord. 685, passed - -75; Ord. 785, passed - -82; Ord.
1305, passed 3-6-06) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.02 PUBLIC NUISANCE.
   It is unlawful for any person to permit or allow any animal of the species
listed in §
94.01 to become a public nuisance.
(‘82 Code, § 6.04.020) (Ord. 685, passed - -75; Ord. 785, passed - -82)
Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.03 ANIMAL TRAFFIC HAZARDS.

listed in §
94.01 to run at large within the city or to become a traffic hazard in the
city.
(‘82 Code, § 6.04.030) (Ord. 685, passed - -75; Ord. 785, passed - -82)

94.99

   It is unlawful for any person to permit or allow any animal of the species
listed in §
94.01 to become in any way a threat to the health or welfare of any person.
(‘82 Code, § 6.04.040) (Ord. 685, passed - -75; Ord. 785, passed - -82)
Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.05 DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMAL AT LARGE.
   It is unlawful for any person to permit or allow any dangerous or vicious
animal to run at large within the city.
(‘82 Code, § 6.04.070) (Ord. 785, passed - -82) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.06 DOMESTIC ANIMALS AFFLICTED WITH DISEASES.
   It is unlawful for any person to allow any animal afflicted with any
contagious or infectious disease to run at large or to be exposed in any public
place whereby the health of man or animal may be affected; nor shall any such
animal be shipped or removed from the premises of the owner thereof except
under the supervision of the Chief of Police or the appropriate health officer.
However, if any such animal be impounded under the provisions of this chapter
and not timely claimed, the Chief of Police shall destroy the animal and
properly dispose of the carcass.
(‘82 Code, § 6.04.090) (Ord. 785, passed - -82) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.07 RABIES.
   (A)   Animal muzzling requirement. Whenever the Mayor by proclamation
declares that the danger from rabies is great, it shall be unlawful for any
person to permit or allow any animal upon a public street, alley, sidewalk or
other public place unless such animal is securely muzzled.
(‘82 Code, § 6.08.010)
   (B)   Police power to destroy vicious animals. It is lawful for the Chief of
Police or other police officer to kill any vicious animal at large within the
city limits when such animals cannot be safely taken up and impounded.
(‘82 Code, § 6.08.020)
   (C)   Impoundment and examination of animal.
      (1)   Whenever any animal bites any person, the owner of the animal, or
the person bitten, shall immediately notify the Chief of Police or other police
officer who shall order the animal confined on the owner's premises or shall
have it impounded for a period of two weeks.
      (2)   Any animal so confined or impounded shall be immediately examined
by a qualified veterinarian and shall be again examined by a qualified
veterinarian, in both cases at the owner's expense, at the end of the two
weeks.
      (3)   If at the end of such two-week period the veterinarian is convinced
that the animal is free from rabies, it shall be released from confinement or
impoundment.
      (4)   If during the confinement or impoundment the animal dies, its head
shall be sent to the Department of Health for examination for rabies.
      (5)   Upon notification of an animal bite, the Chief of Police or other
police officer shall fill out an animal bite report and forward it to the
county animal control office.
(‘82 Code, § 6.12.030)
(Ord. 785, passed - -82) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.08 KENNELS.
   (A)   License; fee; sanitation requirement. 
      (1)   It is unlawful for any person to operate a kennel or place for
raising, training or boarding of dogs or cats for hire or profit in the city
without first securing a license therefor.
      (2)   The annual fee for such license shall be an amount to be determined
from time to time by the city.
      (3)   Every owner or operator of a kennel or place for the raising,
training or boarding of dogs or cats for profit shall cause the same to be kept
in a clean and sanitary condition at all times and shall permit the health
officer to inspect or cause to be inspected said kennel at any reasonable time.
(‘82 Code, § 6.12.010)
   (B)   Frontage consent requirement in residential district. No person shall
maintain, conduct or operate any such kennel within a residential district of
the city without first securing the written consent of those persons owning
residential property within 500 feet of the proposed kennel.
(‘82 Code, § 6.12.020)
(Ord. 785, passed - -82) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.09 CRUELTY TO ANIMALS.
   It is unlawful for any person to inhumanely beat, underfeed, overload or
abandon any animal in the city.
(‘82 Code, § 6.20.010) (Ord. 785, passed - -82) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.10 HARBORING OR KEEPING NOISY ANIMAL.
   It is unlawful for any person to keep or harbor any animal which disturbs
the peace by making loud noises.
(‘82 Code, § 6.20.020) (Ord. 785, passed - -82) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.11 SANITATION REQUIREMENTS.
   It is unlawful for any person to cause or allow any place where any animals
are kept to become unclean, unwholesome or odoriferous.
(‘82 Code, § 6.20.040) (Ord. 785, passed - -82) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.12 HUNTING PROHIBITED.
   It is unlawful for any person to engage within the city in the killing,
hunting or trapping of any animal without first obtaining the written
permission of the Public Safety Committee.
(‘82 Code, § 6.20.050) (Ord. 785, passed - -82) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.13 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COMPETENT PERSON. A person who is physically and mentally capable of
managing and controlling a dog, which is in his or her responsibility while on
or off their premises.
   DANGEROUS DOG.
      (1)   Any individual dog which, when unmuzzled, unleashed, or unattended
by its owner or a member of its owner's family, in a vicious or terrorizing
manner, approaches any person in an apparent attitude of attack upon any
street, sidewalk or any public or private property within the city.
      (2)   The county animal control administrator, or his or her duly
authorized representative, or a law enforcement officer, shall make the
determination that a dog is a DANGEROUS DOG, after an investigation has been
conducted.
      (3)   The finding will be made in writing, and shall be hand delivered to
the owner or person keeping the dog, or delivered by both certified mail and by
first class mail to their last known address through the U.S. Postal Service.
Delivery by certified mail shall be considered properly delivered if the
certified mail is returned to the city with a notation that delivery was
refused or unclaimed.
      (4)   It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any dangerous dog to
leave the premises of its owner when the dog is not securely muzzled and
restrained with a leash having a tensile strength of no less than 300 pounds
and not exceeding three feet in length, and under the direct control and
supervision of the owner or keeper of the dog.
      (5)   Any dog defined as a dangerous dog under the Illinois Animal
Control Act, ILCS Ch. 510, Act 5.
   DIRECT CONTROL. The immediate, continuous physical control of a dog by means
of a leash and controlled by a person, or a secure fence, or enclosure of such
strength to restrain the dog, or safe and secure restraint within a vehicle.
Electronic underground fences, ("Invisible Fence") will not be permitted as a
direct control device. DIRECT CONTROL shall not apply to law enforcement K-
9 participating in training or in the course of their official duties. A dog
will be considered "under adequate restraint" if it's owner or owner's
representative maintains control by means of a leash, not more than three feet
long.
   LEASH. A chain or other physical restraint having a tensile strength of not
less than 300 pounds.
   MUZZLE. A device constructed of a strong, soft material or of metal,
designed to fasten over the mouth of an animal to prevent the animal from
biting any person or other animal.
   RUNNING AT LARGE. Any dog or animal found off the owner's premises, which is
not accompanied by the owner or representative of the owner, and is not
restrained by a leash or other physical restraint or otherwise directly
controlled so that it may not enter upon the property of others.
   STRAY. Any animal, which is running at large and for which there is no owner
present, or ownership cannot be determined.
   VICIOUS DOG.
      (1)   Any individual dog that when unprovoked inflicts bites or attacks a
human being or other animal either on public or private property.
      (2)   Any individual dog with known propensity, tendency or disposition
to attack without provocation, to cause injury, or to otherwise endanger the
safety of human beings or other animals.
      (3)   Any individual dog which has been found to be a dangerous dog upon
three separate occasions.
      (4)   Any dog defined as a vicious dog under the Illinois Animal Control
Act, ILCS Ch. 510, Act 5.
      (5)   No dog shall be deemed vicious if it bites, attacks or menaces a
trespasser on the property of its owner or harms or menaces anyone who has
tormented or abused it, or is a professionally trained dog for law enforcement.
      (6)   Vicious dogs shall not be classified in a manner that is specific
as to breed, unless permitted by the State of Illinois Animal Control Act.
      (7)   The county animal control administrator or his or her duly sworn
representative or a law enforcement officer shall make the determination that a
dog is a VICIOUS DOG as defined in this section, after an investigation has
been conducted.
      (8)   The finding will be made in writing and shall be hand delivered to
the owner or person keeping the dog, or delivered by both certified mail and by
first class mail to their last known address through the U.S. Postal Service.
Delivery by certified mail shall be considered properly delivered if the
certified mail is returned to the city with a notation that delivery was
refused or unclaimed. At the same time an impoundment order will be delivered
to the owner or keeper of the dog. (Impoundment means taken into custody of the
pound, which is operated by the county.)
      (9)   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any dog
which has been found to be a vicious dog anywhere within the corporate limits
of the city, regardless of the conditions of the animal's enclosure, restraint
or controllability.
      (10)   The owner of any dog in the city which has been found to be
vicious, shall surrender the animal to the pound by order of the county animal
control administrator of his or her duly authorized representative, or the
chief of police or his or her duly authorized representative.
      (11)   If the owner of the vicious dog has not appealed the impoundment
order by filing an appropriate pleading with the Circuit Court of Whiteside
County within seven working days, the dog shall be humanely dispatched.
      (12)   Each day a person fails to comply with the provisions of this
section constitutes a separate offense.
(Ord. 1305, passed 3-6-06)
DOGS AND CATS
§ 94.25 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CAT. Any feline three months or more of age.
   DOG. Any canine three months or more of age.
(‘82 Code, § 6.16.010)
§ 94.26 DOGS AND CATS AT LARGE; IMPOUNDMENT ; REDEMPTION PROCEDURE.
   (A)   It is unlawful for any person to permit any dog or cat upon any public
street, alley, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private lands, except
the private lands of the owner or caretaker of the subject animal, unless such
subject animal is secured by a leash and under the control of a person holding
such leash.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police or other police officer to
capture and impound each and every dog or cat found at large and not on a leash
and without a collar, tag or muzzle. The Chief of Police shall thereupon notify
the owner of the dog or cat so taken, if the owner can be ascertained, and the
owner shall be permitted to redeem the dog or cat within ten days by paying all
license and other fees upon said animal, together with an amount to be
determined from time to time by the city for the cost of keeping such animal
and the cost of advertising, if any, to the city.
   (C)   Should no redemption be made of any dog or cat thus impounded, it
shall be the duty of the pound master to dispose of the dog or cat so
unredeemed at the end of the tenth day in the manner prescribed by the City
Council.
(‘82 Code, § 6.16.020) (Ord. 509, passed - -59; Ord. 785, passed - -82; Am.
Ord. 1003, passed - -)
§ 94.27 TAG REQUIREMENT.
   It is unlawful for any person to permit any dog to be on any public street,
sidewalk, alley or other public place unless such dog has a collar firmly
attached around his or her neck with a license tag for the current year
attached to such collar.
(‘82 Code, § 6.16.030) (Ord. 509, passed - -59; Ord. 785, passed - -82)
Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.28 RABIES INOCULATION REQUIREMENT.
   It is unlawful for any person to permit any dog which is not on a leash,
under control or muzzled to be in any public street, parkway, sidewalk, park,
in any store or place of public gathering or in any place in the city other
than in an enclosed area unless such dog has been inoculated against rabies in
compliance with the terms of the Animal Control Act of the state of Illinois.
(‘82 Code, § 6.16.040) (Ord. 509, passed - -59; Ord. 785, passed - -82)
Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.29 UNSPAYED FEMALE DOGS IN SEASON.
   It is unlawful for the owner of any female dog in season to permit or allow
said dog to run at large, or to confine her as to attract male dogs to the area
and by their presence cause a nuisance. The owner shall keep and confine the
female dog in a place where male dogs will not be attracted thereto or shall
place the female dog at a kennel providing care and keep during the time the
female is in season.
(‘82 Code, § 6.16.050) (Ord. 509, passed - -59; Ord. 591, passed - -66; Ord.
785, passed - -82) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.30 EXCREMENT.
   (A)   Dog excrement. It shall be unlawful for any owner to permit any dog
owned by him or her to defecate on any property, public or private, not owned
by the owner unless the owner has in his or her possession a device for
excrement removal and the owner immediately removes any excrement from such
property to a receptacle on property owned, occupied, or lawfully controlled by
the owner.
   (B)   Cat excrement. It shall be unlawful for any cat owner to permit any
cat excrement to remain on any property, public or private, not owned by the
cat owner upon notification to the cat owner by the person owning, occupying,
or lawfully in control of such property that the owner's cat has defecated on
such property. Upon such notification, the cat owner shall immediately remove
the excrement from such property to a receptacle on property owned, occupied,
or lawfully controlled by said cat owner.
(Ord. 1305, passed 3-6-06) Penalty, see §
94.99
WILD OR EXOTIC ANIMALS
§ 94.40 DEFINITION; APPLICABILITY.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DANGEROUS ANIMAL. Any warm-blooded, carnivorous or omnivorous lion, tiger,
leopard, ocelot, jaguar, cougar, cheetah, margay, mountain lion, lynx, bobcat,
jaguarundi, bear, hyena, wolf, coyote, elephant, nonhuman primate or any
hybrids thereof. A DANGEROUS ANIMAL can also mean any reptile or fish over six
feet in length or reptile or fish that is poisonous or life threatening.
   ENDANGERED SPECIES. A species of animal in danger of becoming extinct as
listed by the United States Government or Illinois State Department of
Agriculture.
   WILD OR EXOTIC ANIMAL. A dangerous animal, endangered species or any animal
which is not commonly considered a domestic animal. An animal which is normally
classified as dangerous or endangered cannot be redefined as a domestic animal
by an attempt by any person to domesticate a dangerous animal or endangered
species.
(Ord. 1089, passed 9-1-98)
§ 94.41 UNLAWFUL TO KEEP CERTAIN ANIMALS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to own, have a right of
property in, keep, harbor, care for, act as custodian of or maintain in his or
her possession or on his or her property any dangerous, wild or exotic animal,
fish, reptile or endangered species, hereinafter collectively referred to as a
"wild animal.”
(Ord. 1089, passed 9-1-98) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.42 SEIZURE.
   If there appears to be imminent danger to the public by reason of a possible
violation of this subchapter, in the sole discretion of any officer of the
Police Department or any law enforcement officer with jurisdiction in the city,
any wild animal found not in compliance with the provisions of this Act shall
be subject to immediate seizure by such law enforcement officer or their
designated agent, and may immediately be placed in a facility and all costs
connected with the seizure, confiscation and boarding of such animal shall be
the responsibility of any person found to own, have a right of property in,
kept, harbor, care for, act as custodian of or maintain in their possession or
on their property, any wild animal as defined under this subchapter.
Furthermore, such person shall be responsible for any costs or reasonable
attorneys fees that may be incurred by the city in collecting from such person
the costs connected with such seizure, confiscation and boarding of any wild
animal.
(Ord. 1089, passed 9-1-98)
§ 94.43 VIOLATIONS.
   Upon the conviction of a person for a violation of this section, the wild
animal with regard to which the conviction was obtained shall be confiscated
and placed in a facility (if not previously confiscated and placed), and the
owner thereof and the person convicted shall be responsible for a costs
connected with the seizure and confiscation of such wild animal and the
boarding of such wild animal from date of seizure to the date the wild animal
is no longer boarded for the person so convicted, all in addition to any other
penalty permitted by the ordinances of the city.
(Ord. 1089, passed 9-1-98) Penalty, see §
94.99
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
§ 94.60 OFFICIAL AUTHORITY TO KILL DANGEROUS ANIMALS.
   Any police officer of the city is authorized to kill any dangerous animal of
any kind when it is necessary for the protection of any person or property.
(‘82 Code, § 6.20.030) (Ord. 785, passed - -82)
§ 94.61 IMPOUNDMENT.
   The Chief of Police or any other police officer is empowered to summarily
impound any animal in violation of this chapter and to hold said animal for a
period of ten days, after which the animal may be sold or destroyed as within
the discretion of the Chief of Police, should the Chief of Police deem
necessary.
(‘82 Code, § 6.04.050) (Ord. 685, passed - -75; Ord. 785, passed - -82)
§ 94.62 RECLAMATION OF ANIMALS; FEES.
   The owner of any animal so impounded may reclaim the animal upon payment of
all costs incurred by the city plus a reclamation fee which shall be determined
from time to time by the city for each such impoundment.
(‘82 Code, § 6.04.060) (Ord. 685, passed - -75; Ord. 785, passed - -82)
§ 94.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter
for which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon conviction,
be subject to a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $750 for each offense.
The minimum fine for each subsequent offense of any violation of this chapter
shall provide for an increase in the minimum fine of $100 for each subsequent
offense, but not more than $750. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
for each day during which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 1368, passed 4-7-08; Am. Ord. 1713, passed - -)
CHAPTER 95: ABANDONED VEHICLES
Section
   
95.01   Definitions
   
95.02   Abandoned vehicle prohibited; notification of police
   
95.03   Authorization for removal
   
95.04   Removal by authorized towing service
   
95.05   Towed vehicle; records
   
95.06   Record search
   
95.07   Notification of state police of inability to identify owner
   
95.08   Reclamation of vehicle by owner
   
95.09   Sale of unclaimed vehicle
   
95.10   Disposition of proceeds of sale
   
95.11   Liability limitation
§ 95.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ABANDONED VEHICLE. All motor vehicles or other vehicles in a state of
disrepair rendering the vehicle incapable of being driven in its condition; or
any motor vehicle or other vehicle that has not been moved or used for seven
consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted.
   ANTIQUE VEHICLE. Any motor vehicle or other vehicle 25 years of age or
older.
   HIGHWAY. Any street, alley or public way within the city.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.010) (Ord. 647, passed - -71)
§ 95.02 ABANDONED VEHICLE PROHIBITED; NOTIFICATION OF POLICE.
   (A)   The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle, or any part
thereof, on any highway in this city is unlawful and subject to penalties as
set forth in §
10.99.
   (B)   The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle, or any part
thereof, on private or public property, other than a highway, in view of the
general public anywhere in this city is unlawful, except on property of the
owner or bailee of such abandoned vehicle for a period of not more than three
months.
   (C)   A motor vehicle or other vehicle, or any part thereof, so abandoned on
private property may be authorized for removal by or upon the order of the
Chief of the Police Department of the city, after a waiting period of seven
days or more has expired.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.020) (Ord. 647, passed - -71)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 95.03 AUTHORIZATION FOR REMOVAL.
   (A)   When an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other
vehicle comes into the temporary possession or custody of a person in this
state, not the owner of the vehicle, such person shall immediately notify the
Police Department when the vehicle is within the corporate limits of the city.
   (B)   Upon receipt of such notification, the Chief of the Police Department
shall authorize a towing service to remove and take possession of the
abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle.
   (C)   The towing service will safely keep the towed vehicle and its contents
and maintain a record of the tow until the vehicle is claimed by the owner or
any other person legally entitled to possession thereof or until it is disposed
of as provided in this chapter.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.030) (Ord. 647, passed - -71)
§ 95.04 REMOVAL BY AUTHORIZED TOWING SERVICE.
   (A)   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is abandoned on a highway in
this city ten hours or more, its removal by a towing service may be authorized
by order of the Chief of the Police Department of this city.
   (B)   When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, burned or partially dismantled
motor vehicle or other vehicle is creating a traffic hazard because of its
position in relation to the highway or its physical appearance is causing the
impeding of traffic, its immediate removal from the highway by a towing service
may be authorized by order of the Chief of the Police Department of this city.
   (C)   When a vehicle removed from either public or private property is
authorized by order of the Chief of the Police Department of this city, the
owner of the vehicle will be responsible for all towing costs.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.040) (Ord. 647, passed - -71)
§ 95.05 TOWED VEHICLES; RECORDS.
   (A)   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is authorized to be towed away,
the Police Department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed
listing the color, year of manufacture, manufacturer's trade name,
manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification number and
license plate year and number displayed on the vehicle.
   (B)   The record shall also include the date and hour of tow, location towed
from, location towed to, reason for towing and the name of the officer
authorizing the tow.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.050) (Ord. 647, passed - -71)
§ 95.06 RECORD SEARCH.
   (A)   When the Police Department does not know the identity of the
registered owner or other legally entitled person, they will cause the motor
vehicle registration records of the state to be searched by a directed
communication to the Secretary of State for the purpose of obtaining the
required ownership information.
   (B)   The Police Department will cause the stolen motor vehicle files of the
Illinois State Police to be searched by a directed communication to the
Illinois State Police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the
Illinois State Police files are searched with negative results, the information
contained in the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) files will be
searched by the Illinois State Police. The information determined from these
record searches will be used by the Police Department in sending a notification
by certified mail to the owner or legally entitled person advising where the
vehicle is held, requesting a disposition be made and setting forth public sale
information.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.060) (Ord. 647, passed - -71)
§ 95.07 NOTIFICATION OF STATE POLICE OF INABILITY TO IDENTIFY OWNER.
   When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession
of a motor vehicle or other vehicle cannot be identified from the registration
files of this state or from the registration files of a foreign state, if
applicable, the Police Department shall notify the Illinois State Police for
the purpose of identifying the vehicle's owner or other person legally entitled
to the possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by the Illinois
State Police will be immediately forwarded to the law enforcement agency having
custody of the vehicle for notification of owner.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.070) (Ord. 647, passed - -71)
§ 95.08 RECLAMATION OF VEHICLE BY OWNER.
   Any time before a motor vehicle or other vehicle is sold at public sale or
disposed of as provided in this chapter, the owner or other person legally
entitled to its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the Police
Department proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the
vehicle. No vehicle shall be released to the owner or other person under this
section until all towing and storage charges have been paid.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.080) (Ord. 647, passed - -71)
§ 95.09 SALE OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLE.
   (A)   Seven years old or newer. 
      (1)   Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or
other vehicle, seven years of age or newer, remains unclaimed by the registered
owner or other person legally entitled to its possession for a period of 30
days after notice has been given as provided herein, the Police Department
having possession of the vehicle shall cause it to be sold at public sale to
the highest bidder.
      (2)   Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be posted in a
conspicuous place for at least ten days prior to the sale on the premises where
the vehicle has been impounded. At least ten days prior to the sale, the Police
Department shall cause a notice of the time and place of the sale to be sent by
certified mail to the registered owner or other person known by the Police
Department or towing service to be legally entitled to the possession of the
vehicle. Such notice shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to be
sold and what steps must be taken by any legally entitled person to reclaim the
vehicle.
      (3)   In those instances where the certified notification specified
herein has been returned by the postal authorities to the Police Department due
to the addressee having moved, or being unknown at the address obtained from
the registration records of this state, the sending of a second certified
notice will not be required.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.090)
   (B)   Older than seven years.
      (1)   When the identity of the registered owner or other person legally
entitled to the possession of an abandoned, lost or unclaimed vehicle of seven
years of age or older cannot be determined by any means provided for in this
chapter, the vehicle may be sold as provided for herein or disposed of in the
manner authorized by this chapter without notice to the registered owner or
other person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle.
      (2)   When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven years of age is
impounded as specified by this chapter, it will be kept in custody for a
minimum of ten days for the purpose of determining ownership, the contacting of
the registered owner by the United States Mail, public service or in person for
a determination of disposition and an examination of the Illinois State Police
stolen motor vehicle files for theft and wanted information.
      (3)   At the expiration of the ten day period, without the benefit of
disposition information being received from the registered owners, the Chief of
Police will authorize the disposal of the vehicle as junk only.
      (4)   A motor vehicle or other vehicle classified as an antique vehicle
is excluded from this chapter.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.100)
   (C)   Record of transaction. When a motor vehicle or other vehicle in the
custody of the Police Department is reclaimed by the registered owner or other
legally entitled person, or when the vehicle is sold at public sale or
otherwise disposed of as provided in this chapter, a report of the transaction
will be maintained by the Police Department for a period of one year from the
date of the sale or disposal.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.110)
(Ord. 647, passed - -71)
§ 95.10 DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS OF SALE.
   When a vehicle located within the corporate limits of this city is
authorized to be towed away by the Chief of Police and disposed of as set forth
in this chapter, the proceeds of the public sale or disposition after the
deduction of towing, storage and processing charges shall be deposited in the
city treasury.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.120) (Ord. 647, passed - -71)
§ 95.11 LIABILITY LIMITATION.
   Any police officer, towing service owner, operator or employee shall not be
held to answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered
owner, former registered owner or his or her legal representative, or any other
person legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle
when the vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by this
chapter.
(‘82 Code, § 10.40.130) (Ord. 647, passed - -71)
